I refer to two people who have done a lot of work in respect of committees in this parliament. The first is Professor Janet Hiebert, who is a professor at the Queen's University in Canada. She has written several articles, but the one I particularly address my attention to is entitled `A hybrid approach to protect rights? An argument in favour of supplementing Canadian judicial review with Australia's model of parliamentary scrutiny'. This article shows that proper parliamentary scrutiny can 
 overcome problems that might arise in legislation.
 The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, which I am honoured to be the chair of, has played its part in that scrutiny. Over the numerous parliaments since I have been here, ministers have cooperated very effectively with that committee in trying to get legislation free of any infringements on human rights. The legislation that does infringe human rights usually does so by accident. When you draft legislation, these things can creep in. I must confess that over the years the executive has usually been keen to see that the legislation does not breach human rights.
 The other person I want to refer to is Frank Brennan, who is probably known to everyone listening to me speak now. He has written a book called Legislating Liberty: a Bill of Rights for Australia? that has recently been published by the University of Queensland Press. Again, he goes into this issue of how parliament can have its input into seeing that civil liberties are properly attended to through the legislature. He argues that the Bill of Rights is certainly not to be put aside, because it can be a very effective means of looking after the liberties of the citizen, but that parliament itself can and should do more. I think we as a parliament should take up the words of Janet Hiebert and Frank Brennan and take their issues forward.
I make the point that the judge on this occasion was fulfilling the grand traditions of the judiciary, that is, he was ensuring that a person—no matter what his background, no matter whether he was good, bad or ugly—was nevertheless given the full protection of the law and that, if his liberty was going to be taken away, then it had to be taken away according to due process and that due process is a very high test—and so it should be.
The next point is that the courts over the years have been protective of the freedom of Australians, as has parliament. We should not overlook that. But this is the occasion and the time for the parliament to look more and more at its part—it would have to be a bipartisan approach—in establishing that legislation in any event does not contain problems in so far as human rights go. This is a good occa 
 sion to raise these issues, today being the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
 The work of both Janet Hiebert and Frank Brennan provides us as a parliament with a way of going forward to ensure that we do walk proud as citizens and that nobody is going to be able to interfere with us, as we do walk proud as citizens, unless the full operation of the law has been called into play. It does mean the full operation. We cannot cut the corners. Once we start cutting corners, then we get instances of injustice, which we want to avoid. I do not want to go through the number of people who have been wrongly convicted and wrongly treated over the years—that will keep going because to err is human. But I think we as an institution can do a lot to ensure that that does not happen as much as it otherwise would.

name: Coonan, Sen Helen
text:
—On behalf of Senator Margetts, I seek leave to incorporate her speech on the second reading of the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1998 .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
1.	 General Themes
The broad issues in this bill relate to achieving a balance between administrative ease or speed and proper oversight of executive decision making. Administrative law in general, is concerned to ensure that the existence of values of fairness, openness, honesty and efficiency in Commonwealth executive dealings with the general public.
Now—I would like to make clear that the Greens (WA) are supportive of the concept of administrative efficiency. Administrative efficiency is beneficial for members of the executive so that they can deal with their business in an optimal fashion without unwieldy red tape. Administrative efficiency is also beneficial for members of the public dealing with the executive. It is not in anyone's interests that government decision-making process should falter on what are no more than mere technicalities. Third parties dealing in good faith with the Commonwealth have a legitimate expectation that arrangements will not be frustrated by administrative oversights beyond their control. In addition, otherwise reasonable and lawful action taken against wrongdoers should not be defeated by technical objections. 

However, administrative efficiency should in no way be confused with administrative ease and speed. The speediest methods of administration are not always the ones that produce the most desirable outcomes. The Greens are concerned that best practice administrative procedures and protocols are in place in our executive arm of government—so that the executive can do their job with certainty, transparency and effectiveness and that the public can go about their business with certainty without having their rights unnecessarily or harshly or unjustly impinged upon.
The Acts Interpretation Act 1901  is one of the central pieces of legislation in this kind of framework. In some instances the Acts Interpretation Act 1901  will operate to confer legal responsibility for particular statutory provisions on persons other than those specifically named in the legislation. Consequently the Acts Interpretation Act in prescribed circumstances works to bring the legal position into line with changes agreed at the administrative and political level. As such, the Greens take very seriously the potentially immense implications of even small changes to this Act.
In effect, the Bill asks the Parliament whether (and to what degree) it is prepared to permit the Executive to exercise a wider discretion than is currently available when altering lines of administrative authority and responsibility delineated by legislation.

Verbal Authorisations
One provision in this amending Bill, which would have had immense implications, is the ability to verbally authorise another Minister. We are pleased to see that the Government has taken on board concerns raised regarding their proposal that a grant of authority may be oral in cases where authority is conferred on a Minister. Oral authorisations are obviously problematic for a number of reasons.
The ability to authorise without a written instrument decreases the transparency in administrative decision making—it makes it hard to engage in proper auditing of these decisions; it creates problems in the enforcement of individual rights—as anyone who is aggrieved by administrative actions would run into evidentiary difficulties, and this would make it more difficult to gain redress through administrative appeal. Oral authorisations could also increase the incidence of court and tribunal proceedings being commenced with the wrong respondent/decision-maker being nominated by the complainant.
The lack of publicity and the lack of a clear paper trail could result in not only in severe injustices for anyone seeking to review or challenge an administrative decision, but in bad practice in Government decision making. Best practice most consistent with the principles of administrative law would be 
 written authorisations for reasons of transparency and accountability. If oral authorisations are legitimate, there would a temptation to pursue this easier and less specific path—which would undercut best practice.
Not only that, but oral authorisations would potentially undermine parliamentary intention in specific pieces of legislation. But I will come back to this point later. For all these reasons—oral authorisations are a good example of where administrative ease or speed would not produce administrative efficiency—and may have produced very poor outcomes all round.
For all these reasons, I am glad that the Government has been persuaded by these arguments and has removed the ability to orally authorise.
2.	 What the Bill Does
This bill is ostensibly a clarification of when it is allowable for a Minister to authorise another Minister or a Parliamentary Secretary to exercise statutory powers on their behalf.
The Bill amends the Acts Interpretation Act 1901  in direct response to the decision of Justice Spender in Foster v Attorney-General  (1998) that has put a question mark over the breadth of s19 in the Acts Interpretation Act. 
Justice Spender's decision in the Foster case means that s19 is not sufficient legislative authority for a portfolio Minister to authorise a junior portfolio Minister to exercise statutory powers vested in the holder of a specific ministerial office (ie vested in the "Attorney General"). So in the Foster case, the Attorney General's authorisation of the Minister of Justice was held to be invalid. Consequently, a decision to issue a warrant purportedly made by the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone, under section 23 of the Extradition Act 1988  was held to be invalid.
This decision, by implication, also means that a portfolio Minister cannot authorise non-portfolio Ministers or Parliamentary Secretaries when powers are vested in a specific Minister.
Essentially this Bill will do a number of things.
(a)	 It will retrospectively validate past authorisations that may have been made in reliance on section 19 to the extent that they may be invalid.
(b)	 It will provide for a Minister to authorise a non-portfolio Minister or Parliamentary Secretary to act on his or her behalf.
(c)	 And it will ensure that an order can be made by the Governor General under section 19 whenever there is any change to the administration of government business and validates past orders under s19BA to the extent that they may be invalid. 

3.	 Concerns
The Greens appreciate the concerns expressed by the Attorney General in relation to Foster . The decision does have potentially serious ramifications for the administrative process of the executive and the Greens will not be preventing this Bill from attempting to address these concerns. The Greens see the merits in remedying the defects of the past. However, we do have concerns that a whole raft delegations or authorisations were done in an informal or non-recorded manner. And we would not like to see our acceptance of past validations as condoning informal delegations/ authorisations in the future.
Of course the issue of retrospectivity is ever present when we are dealing with past delegations. The issue is of injustices in the past that may no longer afford a remedy to an individual. This is always a difficult issue to weigh up. But on balance, as I mentioned previously, I do appreciate the concerns of the Attorney General and the potential for immense difficulties if these past authorisations are not validated.

Parliamentary Oversight
Another concern the Greens have is with the removal of the variance between specific and non-specific references to Ministers. This Bill essentially operates to remove the distinction between more general terms like "the Minister" and highly specific terms like "the Attorney General".
The situation as it currently stands is that when a piece of legislation uses the term "the Minister" this refers to any Minister with responsibility for that portfolio.
However, when a piece of legislation uses the term "the Attorney General" or "the Minister for Finance" or "the Treasurer", this refers specifically to the person currently occupying that position. By naming a particular Minister, there is an assumption that it was Parliament's view that that Minister should be accountable for things done under the Act and should be required to personally perform the statutory functions that the law assigns to her or him.
The amendments in this Bill, by homogenising the distinction between these terms, threaten to usurp parliamentary intention when the legislation was written and agreed to. Although the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct prefers the generic term to avoid potential complications, the legislation handbook recognises that there are appropriate circumstances where parliament should legislate to name a specific minister because of the special skills needed in undertaking a particular duty or function.
Of course, the entire basis of administrative law is that everything requires a specific statutory mandate. Ministers (or anyone else in the executive arm 
 of Government) cannot go off on "a frolic of their own" without reference to a specific statutory authority. So when a piece of legislation says "Attorney General"—it is indicating that there are special skills needed in this area. This should not be overlooked too easily.
The Greens (WA) note that the Attorney General's department is currently undertaking a review of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 . We shall be watching these developments carefully to ensure a good balance is struck. We shall be watching that changes do not ask the Parliament too go too far in permitting the Executive to exercise a wider discretion than is currently available and when altering lines of administrative authority and responsibility delineated by legislation.
While supporting this Bill at Second Reading, the Greens (WA) will carefully consider the amendments in the Committee Stage of this Bill.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I thank senators for their contributions to this debate. The bill provides that all ministerial authorisations that may have been affected by the decision of the Federal Court in the Foster case are validated. Because of the implications of the decision, it is appropriate that urgent legislative action be taken to clarify the position of ministerial authorisations.
The amendments in the bill will ensure that there is no uncertainty about the legal status of decisions made under such authorisations. The bill also clarifies the legal basis for senior portfolio ministers to authorise junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries to exercise statutory powers on their behalf. As senators are aware, the speedy passage of this bill will restore certainty to government administration and facilitate the continued orderly and efficient conduct of government business.
In relation to two matters raised by Senator Stott Despoja, I would say as follows. The government can give the assurance sought by Senator Stott Despoja that there is no political agenda involved with these amendments. Extradition matters or other matters which are sensitive and require review will be capable of review—judicial, administrative and political—in the same manner as occurs at present.
In addition, Senator Stott Despoja wanted an undertaking in the same vein as this sentence: `The amendments will in no way prejudice practice that in the past has ensured due process.' On the contrary, the amendments validate past practice. It will not retrospectively disadvantage anyone.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Sitting suspended from 1.39 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

name: Campbell, Sen George
text: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison. Is the minister aware of a letter dispatched by the former Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin, to coalition senators and MPs in relation to the new workplace agreement for MOPS staff? In particular, is the minister aware that Senator Minchin urged coalition MPs and senators to `support this offer and impress upon their staff the importance of accepting the agreement in their own interests as well as that of the government'? Why was this final paragraph deleted from the letter sent to non-coalition MPs and senators? Does the minister endorse the view that de facto employers should be encouraged to place pressure on their staff to accept for political reasons an offer which the majority agreed by vote was not in their interests?

name: Campbell, Sen George
text:
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what are the government's proposals in relation to further negotiation of a workplace agreement for MOPS staff after the 
 government's own staff overwhelmingly rejected the dud deal?

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text: —I thank Senator George Campbell for that question. I am not aware of the difference that he points to. The question of a certified agreement was taken to the staff, and it is well known that that was rejected. We are continuing consultation with both opposition and government staff in relation to this. In fact, today I will be talking to representatives from the Democrats. We are very keen to get this right. We are endeavouring to sort the matter out.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text: —I thought I had already answered that, but what we are doing is talking to staff and finding out what their concerns are. This is very important. It is a fair enough process, one which the opposition always advocates in relation to industrial relations—consultation. That is what we are embarking upon.

name: Kemp, Sen Rod
text:
—Senator Ray asked me questions yesterday relating to the superannuation surcharge. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard  additional responses to those questions.
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
RESPONSE TO QUESTIONS FROM SENATOR RAY ON THE SUPERANNUATION SURCHARGE
Can the Minister confirm that the Australian Taxation Office is imposing the 15 per cent super tax on deceased Australians?
No.
Assessments are issued to the holders of for member's contributions, generally superannuation providers. They are based on information given to the Commissioner about members' contributions. Basically, if an assessment is raised in relation to a member's, contributions and that member died before the assessment is received by the provider, then the assessment is taken not to have been made in relation to that member's contributions.
How many assessment notices have been sent to deceased taxpayers for the 15 per cent super tax?
The Commissioner of Taxation would not send out a surcharge assessment if he is aware the member has died.
In most cases, assessments are sent to superannuation providers as the holders of members' contributions. However, if a provider ceases to be the holder of a member's contribution (for example, when a member is in receipt of a pension or annuity), any assessment will be issued to the member. If a member dies before an assessment is received, the assessment is taken not to have been made, that is, there is no requirement to pay any assessed surcharge liability in these cases.
Why does the Government believe that it is appropriate to levy the surcharge or super tax on Australians who have not and cannot receive their superannuation because they have died?
Surcharge is calculated on the surchargeable contributions of high income earners and is assessed to the holder of the contributions. As I indicated earlier, if a member dies before the 
 surcharge assessment is received by the holder of the contributions, then the assessment is taken not to have been made and there is no requirement to pay the amount assessed.
How much does the Government anticipate collecting in this matter?
The Government does not anticipate collecting any amount in relation of the surchargeable contributions of high income earners who die before an assessment is received by the holder of the contributions. The law does not allow it.
Would the Minister like to comment on the principle of sending out notices of assessment, which are quite appropriate with income tax and other matters, to people who have died and are not able to access their benefit to superannuation but who still have to pay the tax on it? Can you see that that is quite a different principle to any other tax imposition for a deceased person? Can you imagine the distress it causes to those managers and beneficiaries of the estate? Can you tell us what the situation is, how many people are affected, what the value of it is and how you rationalise the principle of the matter?
The Commissioner of Taxation would not send out a surcharge assessment if he is aware the member has died. If the Commissioner is not aware of the death and an assessment subsequently issues, there is no requirement to pay the assessed surcharge liability.

name: Ellison, Sen Chris
text:
—I present the government's response to the 
 President's report of 2 July 1998 on outstanding government responses to parliamentary committee reports. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The response read as follows—
GOVERNMENT RESPONSES TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS
RESPONSE TO THE SCHEDULE TABLED BY THE DEPUTY PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE ON 2 JULY 1998
Circulated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate
Senator the Hon Robert Hill
10 December 1998
COMMUNITY AFFAIRS REFERENCES
Access to medical records
The Government is considering its response following consultations with key stakeholders. It is anticipated that the response will be finalised in the near future.
Housing Assistance
The Government response was presented out of session to the President of the Senate on 26 November 1998.
Public Dental Services in Australia
The Government is considering the report and it is anticipated that the response will be finalised in the near future.
COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES (Senate Select)
Overseas sourced audiotex services, video and computer games, R-rated material on pay TV
The Government response is expected to be tabled in the near future.
Regulation of computer on-line services—part 2
Regulation of computer on-line services—part 3
The Government will respond to these reports jointly. This will enable the response to reflect Government decisions on a regulatory framework for on-line content. The detail of the framework is currently being finalised with draft legislation expected to be available in the first half of 1999.
Report on the Portrayal of Violence in the Electronic Media
The Government response is expected to be tabled in the near future.
ECONOMICS LEGISLATION
Australian Prudential Regulation Authority Bill 1998, and ten related bills
The bills were passed by the Senate on 22 June 1998. The Senate Committee noted that the 
 Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions Supervisory Levy Imposition Bill 1998 provided for commencement to be delayed by a period of substantially greater than the period referred to in Office of Parliamentary Council Drafting Instruction No. 2 of 1989. The Committee noted the reason given for this in the relevant Explanatory Memorandum and made no recommendation. The Government does not intend to provide a separate formal response.
Provisions of the Trade Practices Amendment (Country of Origin Representations) Bill 1998
The bill was passed in an amended form by the Senate on 8 July 1998. The Government does not intend to respond further to this report.
ELECTORAL MATTERS (Joint Standing)
Industrial Elections: Report of the inquiry into the role of the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) in conducting industrial elections.
The Government response was presented out of session to the President of the Senate on 29 July 1998.
EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING REFERENCES
A class act: inquiry into the status of teachers and development of the teaching profession
The Government response is expected to be tabled in the 1999 autumn sittings.
ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION, COMMUNICATIONS AND THE ARTS LEGISLATION
Provisions of the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998
The Committee's recommendations were addressed by debate of the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998. The Government does not intend to table a separate response.
Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998
Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998
The bills were passed by the Senate on 2 July 1998. The Government does not intend to provide a separate formal response.
ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION, COMMUNICATIONS AND THE ARTS REFERENCES
Marine and coastal pollution
The Government response was presented out of session to the President of the Senate on 26 November 1998.
FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION REFERENCES
Property Management in the Australian Public Service
The Government is considering its response to this report given major changes in Commonwealth property policy and public sector reforms 
 such as privatisation of government businesses and further devolution of responsibility to departmental heads. The response is expected to be tabled in the 1999 autumn sittings.
Inquiry on the contracting out of government services
The Government response was presented out of session to the President of the Senate on 26 November 1998.
FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE (Joint Standing)
Defence Sub-committee: Visit to Sydney Harbour foreshores defence properties, 14 November 1997
The Government response is expected to be tabled in the near future.
Australia and ASEAN: Managing change
The Government response is close to completion and is expected to be tabled in the 1999 autumn sittings.
Funding of Australia's Defence
The Government response is expected to be tabled in the near future.
Improving butAustralia's regional dialogue on human rights
Preparation of the Government response is well advanced and it is expected to be tabled in the 1999 autumn sittings.
Australia's trade relationship with India
Preparation of the Government response is well advanced and it is expected to be tabled in the 1999 autumn sittings.
LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS (Senate Standing)
Off the record—shield laws for journalists' confidential sources
The `Off the Record' report is the only report that has been tabled as part of the committee's wide ranging inquiry into the rights and obligations of the media generally. The report was tabled in October 1994. The report considers only one aspect of the terms of reference given to the Committee (ie whether the media should be able to protect the identity of sources of information). These recommendations were conditional upon the media adopting a new code of ethics and an effective disciplinary mechanism for enforcing the code. The Government has been closely monitoring developments since 1995 towards the adoption of a new code of ethics by the Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance.
The report also raises issues that are related to other aspects of the Committee's inquiry.
Given the desirability of a comprehensive Government response to all aspects of the 
 committee's terms of reference, the Government does not propose to respond to the report.
LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL LEGISLATION
Copyright Amendment (No. 2) Bill 1997
On 1 April 1998 the Committee released its report on the Copyright Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997.  By majority, the Committee supported the passage of the bill but raised four matters for consideration by the Government.
The bill was subsequently debated and passed in the Senate on 12 July 1998 effectively providing the Government's response to the Committee's first recommendation that the bill be passed. During debate the Government introduced a number of amendments that responded to the Committee's fifth and final recommendation—to examine the effect that the bill might have on music composers where a CD containing their work is imported.
The Government also took further advice from the Attorney-General's Department, as recommended in the Committee's second recommendation, confirming that the form of the legislation as passed was consistent with the World Trade Organisation's TRIPS agreement.
The two remaining recommendations of the Committee concern matters of more general policy and the Government will provide a response on those matters, as part of the formal response to the report as a whole, by the end of the year.
The preparation of the bill for debate and passage, and the subsequent calling of the Federal election in August 1998, has contributed to the delay in not responding to the report within the agreed timeframe.
Special benefit provisions—Newly arrived resident's waiting period
As the report concluded that there was no need to vary the provisions regarding access to Special Benefit, and contained no recommendations for future action, it is not intended to provide a Government response to this report.

NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (Joint Statutory)

The Committee's report, which was tabled on 6 April 1998, contained a number of recommendations to the Government concerning the powers and operations of the National Crime Authority (NCA). The complex nature of the recommendations required extensive consultation to be undertaken with a number of agencies, including members of the Inter-Governmental Committee (IGC) on the NCA.
Subject to further consultation with the IGC, the Government is expecting to table its response in the 1999 autumn sittings.
NATIVE TITLE AND THE ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER LAND FUND (Joint)

PUBLIC ACCOUNTS AND AUDIT (Joint Statutory)

As a matter of general practice this explanatory schedule does not include reports from the Joint

Reports that address administrative or operational matters are usually responded to in the form of Finance Minutes. These are normally provided to the Committee within six months of the tabling of the report and are then tabled by the Committee.

Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 (Report No. 356)
The Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit made 17 recommendations, most of which related to the technical content of the bill (recommendations 3, 6, 9 and 11 to 17). The Government has already approved and given effect to all of these `technical content' recommendations by sponsoring amendments of the bill in the House of Representatives. The remaining recommendations relate to the Tax Law Improvement Project (TLIP) more generally.
In its tax reform package A New Tax System  under the heading Subsume the Tax Law Improvement Project  (page 149), the Government indicated that it would be giving further consideration as to how to best make use of the considerable experience developed by the TLIP, in developing the proposed integrated tax code. Accordingly, the resources of the Project will be made available to assist in the implementation of the Government's tax reform package. The Government has, therefore, delayed its response until the precise details of the future of the TLIP (and its relationship with the integrated tax code) are settled.

PRESIDENT'S REPORT TO THE SENATE ON GOVERNMENT RESPONSES OUTSTANDING TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS AS AT 10 DECEMBER 1998

PREFACE
This document continues the practice of presenting to the Senate twice each year a list of Government responses to Senate and joint committee reports as well as responses which remain outstanding.
The practice of presenting this list to the Senate follows the resolution of the Senate of 14 March 1973 and the undertaking by successive governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in timely fashion. On 26 May 1978 the then Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Withers) informed the Senate that within six months of the tabling of a committee report, the responsible Minister would make a statement in the Parliament outlining the action the Government proposed to take in relation to the report. The period for responses was reduced from six months to three months in 1983 by the then incoming government. The then Leader of the Government in the Senate announced this change on 24 August 1983. The method of response continued to be by way of statement. Subsequently, on 16 October 1991 the former Government advised that responses to committee reports would be made by letter to a committee chairman, with the letter being tabled in the Senate at the earliest opportunity. The current Government in June 1996 affirmed its commitment to respond to relevant parliamentary committee reports within three months of their presentation.
The list does not usually include reports of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works or the following Senate Standing Committees: Appropriations and Staffing, Selection of Bills, Privileges, Procedure, Publications, Regulations and Ordinances and Scrutiny of Bills. However, such reports will be included if they require a response. Government responses to reports of the Public Works Committee are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered. Responses to reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes which are tabled by the committee. Where a response has been made by way of Finance Minute, the date of presentation has been appropriately annotated.

Legislation committees report on bills and on the provisions of bills. Only those reports in this category that make recommendations which cannot readily be implemented through the bill, and therefore require a response, are listed. The list also does not include reports by legislation committees on estimates.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—I move opposition amendment No. 1:
(1)	 Schedule 1, items 1 and 2, page 3 (line 5) to page 4 (line 23), omit the items, substitute:
1 After section 18B
	 Insert:
18C The Prime Minister or Cabinet may authorise a non-portfolio Minister or a member of the Executive Council who is not a Minister to act on his or her behalf in the performance of statutory functions or the exercise of statutory powers
	 (1)	 The Prime Minister or Cabinet may during the temporary absence or incapacity of a Minister (the  portfolio Minister ) who administers (whether alone or jointly with one or more other Ministers) an Act or a provision of an Act authorise:
		 (a)	 a Minister who does not administer the Act or provision; or
		 (b)	 a member of the Executive Council who is not a Minister;
		 to act on behalf of the portfolio Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the portfolio Minister may perform or exercise under the Act or provision.
	 (2)	 A portfolio Minister with overall responsibility for the portfolio (the  senior portfolio Minister ) may authorise: 

		 (a)	 a Minister who is responsible for certain matters within that portfolio (the  junior portfolio Minister ); or
		 (b)	 a member of the Executive Council who is not a Minister and who is responsible for certain matters within that portfolio;
		 to act on behalf of the senior portfolio Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the senior portfolio Minister may perform or exercise under an Act or a provision of an Act.
	 (3)	 An authorisation under subsection (1) or (2) in relation to an Act or a provision of an Act extends to the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the portfolio Minister or senior portfolio Minister may perform or exercise under an instrument (including a regulation, rule or Proclamation) having effect under or for the purposes of the Act or provision.
	 (4)	 Subject to subsections (5) and (6), an authorisation under subsection (1) or (2) may be expressed:
		 (a)	 to have effect only during a period or periods, or during the existence of a circumstance or circumstances, referred to in the authorisation; or
		 (b)	 to take effect immediately, or at a time referred to in the authorisation, and afterwards to continue to have effect until another person is appointed to the office held by the authorising Minister.
	 (5)	 Despite subsection (4), an authorisation under subsection (1) may be revoked at any time by the Prime Minister or Cabinet.
	 (6)	 Despite subsection (4), an authorisation under subsection (2) may be revoked at any time by the senior portfolio Minister.
	 (7)	 An authorisation under subsection (1) or (2) given to a Minister or member of the Executive Council, and the revocation of such an authorisation, must be in writing.
	 (8)	 This section does not affect the giving, under a power existing apart from this section, of an authorisation to a Minister or other member of the Executive Council to act on behalf of another Minister.
	 (9)	 Either the portfolio Minister or the senior portfolio Minister, or the Minister or member of the Executive Council who acted on behalf of the portfolio Minister or the senior portfolio Minister, as the case may be, may be named as respondent in any proceeding to review the decision. 

	 (10)	 In this section:
 Cabinet  refers to the group of Ministers who are designated as Cabinet Ministers in details of the Ministry issued by the Prime Minister.
 function  includes duty.
Validation of past authorisations
(1)	 Any authorisation that a Minister (the  authorising Minister ) purported to give before the commencement of item 1 to another Minister or member of the Executive Council to act on behalf of the authorising Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the authorising Minister was empowered to perform or exercise under an Act or a provision of an Act is taken to have been, at all times before that commencement when the authorisation purported to be in force, as valid as it would have been if that authorisation had been made by the Prime Minister or Cabinet in accordance with item 1 and the section inserted by that item had been in force when the purported authorisation was given.
(2)	 If an authorisation that a Minister (the  authorising Minister ) purported to give before the commencement of item 1 to another Minister or member of the Executive Council to act on behalf of the authorising Minister in the performance of functions, or the exercise of powers, that the authorising Minister was empowered to perform or exercise under an Act or a provision of an Act purported to be in force immediately before that commencement, the purported authorisation has the effect after that commencement that it would have if that authorisation had been made by the Prime Minister or Cabinet in accordance with item 1 and the section inserted by that item had been in force when the purported authorisation was given.
As I indicated in the second reading debate, the opposition's concern is that the government goes too far in what it is attempting to do here. We understand that there is a problem. We understand that the government wants flexibility, but we think the government goes too far and, in doing so, in some ways may give authority for ministers to in fact override laws passed by this parliament.
Our concern is that ministers should not be able to delegate or authorise outside of their portfolio areas. That should be a responsibility of the Prime Minister or cabinet. We think 
 that should be so for good policy and administrative reasons. There needs to be certainty. Individuals need to know who is taking decisions as to their existence, their businesses and so on. The current government proposal does not do that.
We are also concerned to keep in mind the words of His Honour when he tackled the case of Foster v. Attorney-General. In the judgment, as I cited earlier, Justice Spender made mention of the separation of powers under the Westminster system. Our amendment would offer protection against impingement on such separation of powers. I indicated before lunch that we would move this amendment. The Democrats indicated they would not support it. As a consequence, I will not be putting it to a vote.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I rise to speak on the amendment moved by the opposition. As Senator Bolkus has indicated, the Democrats will not be supporting the amendment in its current form. Clause 18C makes provision for the Prime Minister or cabinet to authorise a non-portfolio minister or a member of the Executive Council who is not a minister to act for or on behalf of the portfolio holder. Although the Democrats have some reservations about the way this amendment operates in that it may not achieve its intended purpose, we are certainly quite glad that it is being proposed as a matter of discussion and debate.
The Acts Interpretation Act was assented to on 12 July 1901 as the second act in the new Australian Federation. Since then, the sections covered by the government's bill have been amended a number of times to deal with changes in the way government operates. The idea supporting interpretation legislation has been a significant reduction in the amount of legislation because commonly used words and phrases can be relied upon. This was evident from a number of submissions to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report entitled Clearer Commonwealth law in September 1993. That report recommended the Attorney-General's Department and the Office of 
 Parliamentary Counsel publicly review and rewrite the Acts Interpretation Act.
As I have set out before, the Democrats are keen to see this process advanced and encourage the government to rewrite this important act to reflect modern day times and needs and responsibilities. However, we also want to see that review and rewrite go further than just the interpretation measures. We want to see the Acts Interpretation Act deal with the institution of government and the way the executive organises itself and distributes the powers granted to government by our laws. We acknowledge the importance of the Acts Interpretation Act, and we want to ensure its continuing relevance and to promote legislative clarity so that those relying on legislation can know and understand what our parliament does and how laws are to take effect. More importantly, we want to make sure those challenging governments or who are subjected to the action of a government can ensure our laws are properly and appropriately administered.
The constitution makes provision for ministers and the federal Executive Council, but it does not distinguish between senior ministers, junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries. The Labor amendment, in many ways, is a welcome recognition of the central place of cabinet in the Australian government as well as these additional roles which reflect the changing way that government is administered. This recognition is now probably as important as ever before. This is because the changes to mega departments by the previous government, as I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate, have been carried on by this government. It is also important to realise the increasing scope of government in Australia.
The constitution makes provision for only seven ministers. At the time the Acts Interpretation Act was assented there were 10 ministers. In 1998 there are some 30 ministers. Perhaps more interesting is the rise of parliamentary secretaries. They first appeared in the Lyons ministry in 1938, with parliamentary secretaries for defence and Treasury. Since then, they have existed in a number of government departments. In 1980 
 they became statutory office holders, and from 1990 they have become members of the Executive Council.
The Democrats are keen to see a reflection of these  changes in the Acts Interpretation Act. We welcome the Labor Party's recognition of these issues and their attempts to put them into effect. Unfortunately, we have some concerns about how these amendments have proposed to achieve their goal. We are of the view that they do not cover satisfactorily the complex issues. However, I understand we have a common interest in reviewing the Acts Interpretation Act to deal with this and related issues. I look forward to hearing the result of this reform process.
The Democrats will not be supporting the amendment in its present form with an understanding from the government that the Acts Interpretation Act is under review and that that review will be completed soon, we hope. We would expect to see the outcome of this review, as I stated in my speech in the second reading debate, in legislation before the parliament, addressing, in particular, the entire issue of the distribution of powers between the Executive Council and others. The Labor Party have flagged their support for this proposition, and I look forward to the government making the same commitment.

name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
text:
—I thank Senator Stott Despoja for indicating the support of the Democrats for the Acts Interpretation Amendment Bill 1998 . I freely acknowledge that there are wider issues to be canvassed under the review, and I expect the Democrats and others will want to make submissions to that review of the Acts Interpretation Act, but their approach is a sensible approach to a potential problem we face. It has been well canvassed in the speeches in the second reading debate that a Federal Court judge has drawn an unexpected interpretation of the Acts Interpretation Act which has put a number of decisions at risk across a number of portfolios. That matter is under appeal, but the judgment has not yet been handed down. In the meantime, there is an absolute need to protect those decisions that have been made, obviously for the longer 
 term, irrespective of the decision to deal with this matter.
I thank the Democrats for their support and confirm our commitment to the proper review of the Acts Interpretation Act that is already under way. I thank the opposition for their interest, in the sense of coming up with alternative amendments, but simply indicate, for reasons I think that are obvious, that they are not satisfactory.
Amendment not agreed to.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I rise to speak on the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 , the Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 1998  and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance) Bill 1998 . I indicate on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, the opposition in the Senate, that we support Senator Lees's second reading amendment to the private health insurance bills. That amendment provides:
"the Senate:
(a)	 notes the evidence provided to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee that the rebate scheme will not take the pressure off public hospitals and is an inefficient and inequitable use of public funds; and
(b)	 resolves that the bill not be read a second time; and
(c)	 calls on the Government to:
	 (i)	 introduce a means test to restrict eligibility for the rebate to hospital insurance for people on low incomes;
	 (ii)	 implement a review process to evaluate the rebate scheme against defined outcome measures;
	 (iii)	 require health insurance funds to achieve improved performance outcomes; and
	 (iv)	 address the key areas of need in the public health sector, including coordinated care for older Australians; waiting lists in public hospitals; public dental health services; rural health services; and the health care needs of indigenous Australians."
These measures highlight the concerns that have been expressed about the inadequacies of this bill. We think the amendment ought to be supported by the Senate. The problems with the proposed bills have been widely canvassed in the second reading debate. It is clear that this is bad public policy. It will not relieve the pressure on the public hospital system. Most of the funds will be directed to 
 those on high incomes who are already in private health insurance. A myth has been perpetrated by the government in this debate that somehow this measure is about assisting, via the rebate, low and middle income families who are battling to meet their insurance costs. The reality is that they will have a very small increase in the rebate that is available currently under the old scheme. Most of the money in this proposal goes to high income earners. Those earning over $70,000 a year are the ones that benefit most. The majority of the funds go to them.
We think that is inequitable. There are major problems in our public hospitals system and this sort of money would go a long way to addressing them. It would not only address those problems but mean that 100 per cent of the Australian population would have the benefit of those funds; that 100 per cent of the population could access good quality public hospital care, rather than just supporting the 30 per cent who are in private health insurance, as is proposed by the government.
It also does not solve the problems with the industry. The gap payments, the out-of-pocket expenses, are so high that a lot of people just cannot afford to use their insurance, even if they have it. That is a real problem in the industry. It is a problem that is not addressed in the bills. It means that this rebate will just get eaten up without solving the very real problems that exist in the health industry.
The other major problem it does not address is rising premiums. People in private health insurance know that their premiums have gone up 16 to 20 per cent in the last two years each year. That means that at this rate any benefit they get out of this measure proposed by the government would get eaten away in higher premiums within a couple of years. People will be no better off.
The measure is also highly inequitable, as I said. About $900 million of the additional $1.4 billion will go to families that already have insurance who are on high incomes. We are throwing money at the well-off in the community while denying funding for services, such as emergency dental care, for those who cannot afford to get treatment otherwise. It is just a wrong set of priorities 
 by the government. They are throwing money at a scheme with no real idea what it will do to the industry and with no real idea whether it will halt the slide. 
The government claimed the last scheme would halt the slide in private health insurance participation, and it did not. They have no statistical or economic modelling to suggest that this will be any more successful, but they will have wasted $1.7 billion of taxpayers' money by throwing it at the problem, not knowing whether it is going to work or not. They got it wrong last time and I suspect they will get it wrong this time.
The proposed amendment by the Democrats seeks to ensure that the pressure on the public hospital system is relieved, that the Dental Health Scheme is reintroduced and that the health needs of indigenous Australians and those in rural areas are addressed. It would ensure that the rebate would be means tested to ensure that it is targeted at middle and low income earners, at the people who need the help to pay the premium, not at John Howard, who does not need the help.
John Howard and people like him will benefit most from this measure. We will basically pay their private health insurance as a result of this measure. That is not what the health needs of this country are. That is not the priority. John Howard and other ministers in this government do not need help to pay their premiums, but people do need to get access to public hospitals and they do need to get off waiting lists to have operations performed when they are in pain. There is a whole range of health needs that are a far more urgent priority for this parliament than subsidising wealthy people to have health insurance.
We are not opposing support for those who need it, but we are opposing providing support for those who do not. As I say, there are some very good things in the Democrats' second reading amendment. It provides a much better direction for public policy in this area and the opposition will be supporting it.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Tambling) proposed:
That the resumption of the debate be an order of the day for a later hour.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text: —As the government has been pressuring us to bring on this debate for weeks and has been saying how important it was we get on with it, I think it is only reasonable that this chamber have an explanation as to why the government is not ready to proceed. I am not opposing the adjournment, if that is the government's view, but it seems to me that we are entitled to an explanation as to why it is not ready to proceed.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—Whilst we have certainly sought to accommodate a good timetable and to accommodate the wishes of the Senate in meeting an adequate timetable today, it is important that the views of all senators be properly taken into account. I hope that we would be able to resume the debate as soon as possible, but at this stage it is in order to accommodate Senator Harradine.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I wanted to check with the minister—I did ask a question, but I did not get a response from him—whether ASIO officer operatives would potentially be exposed to almost unlimited levels of radiation in the course of their job as a result of this legislation. It seems to me that there is the ability for entire health and safety issues for particular categories of people, such as those people working for ASIO, to be isolated in this legislation.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —These issues had been addressed prior to lunch in the answers I gave at that point in regard to the role of the Director-General and the objectives of the act.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I understand that the government argues that this amendment is impossible to support because defence and national security will in some way be prejudiced. The Democrats have always been fairly sceptical about the defence and national security requirements every time we happen to deal with something that involves radioactivity.
 I understand that the Minister for Foreign Affairs met yesterday with a group to discuss nuclear weaponry. By all reports, he was disappointed that they failed to appreciate how much good he is doing to prevent the defence uses of nuclear weapons. Recent surveys highlight the very clear difference between public sentiment about nuclear weapons and the activities of governments all around the world, but particularly the nuclear weapons nations. We believe the Australian government is out of step with the community here. Despite the good intentions of the foreign minister, we do not believe that he is doing enough or that he is necessarily going far enough.
It was significant that the group who met with the foreign minister pointed out last 
 night on the radio the failings of the BJP government in India to focus on the nuclear detonations as a success of their office. This is significant, because we have been led to believe that there was great community support for those detonations and for the escalation of nuclear weaponry in India and in Pakistan. Clearly, the community does not necessarily share the same level of joy or have the same agenda as their government's. This was also obvious in the Rajasthan elections where the chief minister campaigned on the bomb, only to be ousted because the community was more interested in social problems such as whether or not there was enough food.
I suggest that the same thing is likely to happen in a nation like ours. It is probably time for our government to take a lead and do something to force the nuclear weapon states to get rid of their nuclear weapons.
—Hear, hear!
—Thank you, Senator Margetts. It is good to see the Greens support this notion. We certainly support your amendment, Senator Margetts.
This brings me back to the reliance on the defence and national security clauses in this bill. There is no place for these provisions in this bill, because the community does not want them there. Both subclauses 7(1) and 8 (1) are so broad that their application is uncertain. It is quite nebulous as a result. They effectively apply to anything that may affect Australia's defence or national security. What this means is pretty unclear.
 Add to this the obvious public disenchantment with the use of nuclear material in defence and national security, and we cannot support these incredibly broad provisions. If the government want to do this, then they should at least define what they mean and set this out in other legislation. We believe everyone in Australia should comply with the same standards, and exceptions need to be clearly identified and defined.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—The comments of both Senator Margetts and 
 Senator Stott Despoja have been noted and will be passed to the relevant ministers. As I said earlier, the role of the Director-General is one that must take account of the objectives of the legislation.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—You will remember that before lunch I raised the matter, because it is pertinent here, of the Director of Safeguards  report for this year through Foreign Affairs and Trade. The report points out that there is research and development being undertaken at Lucas Heights into the uranium enrichment process under the auspices of Silex Systems Pty Ltd, which has now combined with a United States company and a South African nuclear corporation. I asked the minister what he could tell the committee about this matter as I had raised it before in the chamber. I particularly drew his attention to the following comment on page 31 of the report to his government:
If this technology—
which is being developed in Lucas Heights—
is classified as "associated technology", then any transfer to the US for further development will require an amendment to the existing Australia/US nuclear cooperation agreement, or a new agreement.
I asked whether that was so. I also asked whether, in order to accommodate this research into uranium enrichment, the government is moving to throw out, dismantle or change the nuclear cooperation agreement with the United States and, if so, why.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I will address the specific issue put by Senator Brown but, before doing so, can I have the indulgence of the committee for a moment to comment on some related matters that he raised in the debate yesterday about mining at both Kakadu and Pine Creek. I advise Senator Brown that his concerns on both these matters have been passed on to the relevant minister. With regard to Kakadu, oral advice has been received from the Office of the Supervising Scientist that the recent weather conditions in the Northern Territory have not caused any environmental problems at Ranger.
The senator would, of course, be familiar with the very satisfactory record of the Rang 
 er mine in that area over 18 years. I do not have particular information on the issue regarding Pine Creek. However, I assure the senator that it has been passed to a number of both Commonwealth and Northern Territory ministers for their early attention. As soon as I have any information on it, I will make it available to Senator Brown.
With regard to Silex and the laser issues, I am advised that the Silex project is a private sector project researching a possible method of enriching uranium for use in power reactors. This research is still at an early stage and it is not yet established that the Silex process will be effective in enriching uranium. The Silex company has a contract with the United States Enrichment Corporation for the commercial development of the process in the US if the research is successful.
It is too early to say whether the Silex process is of possible proliferation significance. However, security measures have been put in place to ensure that the technology is protected against unauthorised access. The Australian Safeguards and Non-proliferation Office is monitoring the process of the project to ensure that appropriate security is maintained.
Australian and US officials have been discussing a new agreement to ensure that if the technology is transferred to the US it will be used for exclusively peaceful purposes under international atomic energy safeguards. There is nothing inconsistent with Australia's non-proliferation commitments in undertaking this research. On the contrary, this enhances Australia's capacity to evaluate nuclear developments in other countries and to contribute to the development of effective non-proliferation controls. Examples are international safeguards and controls on the export of relevant technology. For these reasons, the research was authorised by the previous government.
The project does not represent any risk to the environment or public safety. It is extremely small scale. Silex is authorised to process no more than one kilogram of uranium. In practice, much less than this is being used in the process. Information on the project and safeguard arrangements applying 
 to it is given in the annual report of the Director of Safeguards, the head of ANSO.
I trust that that provides Senator Brown with information. I ask him to address any other questions that he may have specifically to this legislation, which we are keen to process in a reasonably ordered timetable today.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I assure the parliamentary secretary that I will not take much longer. I recognise that he had a written response. I wonder whether I could have a copy of it.
—Yes.
—I thank the minister for agreeing to that. I recognise that the parliamentary secretary may not be able to answer these questions. If he cannot, I would again be happy to receive a later reply. Specifically, what in the Australia-US nuclear cooperation agreement would need to be changed to accommodate this research into uranium enrichment and, I am told, potential plutonium enrichment at Lucas Heights? Will there be a transfer to the US for the further use and development of this technology? Why is the research not being done in the US?
When the minister says that special safeguards are being put in place to make this research safe, what exactly are those safeguards? In what way are they being implemented? Finally, is there any other known case of research of this variety which has the potential to enhance the production of nuclear weapons occurring at Lucas Heights or anywhere else in Australia? Can the government be more specific in saying what it means by it not being known whether this has the potential for nuclear weapons development when prima facie it does?
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I will take those questions on notice and provide a detailed response to Senator Brown. I also take this opportunity to offer to him the availability of a comprehensive briefing on this by the safeguards office and other government officers, if necessary.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I thank the parliamentary secretary for that. I accept the offer. I am very keen to follow up this matter.
—The question is that clauses 7 and 8 stand as printed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—by leave—I move Government amendments Nos 2 to 10:
(2)	 Clause 14, page 10 (after line 21), after paragraph (e), insert:
		 (ea)	 to monitor the operations of ARPANSA, the Council, the Radiation Health Committee and the Nuclear Safety Committee;
		 (eb)	 to report on the operations of ARPANSA, the Council, the Radiation Health Committee and the Nuclear Safety Committee.
(3)	 Clause 20, page 13 (after line 2), after subclause (3), insert:
	 (3A)	 Before appointing a member, the Minister must consult such consumer groups and such environmental groups as the Minister considers appropriate.
(4)	 Clause 23, page 14 (after line 8), after subclause (3), insert:
	 (3A)	 Before appointing a member, the CEO must consult such consumer groups and such environmental groups as the CEO considers appropriate.
(5)	 Clause 26, page 15 (after line 15), after subclause (3), insert:
	 (3A)	 Before appointing a member, the CEO must consult such consumer groups and such environmental groups as the CEO considers appropriate. 

(6)	 Clause 31, page 19 (line 11), at the end of subclause (3), add ", and must also take into account international best practice in relation to radiation protection and nuclear safety".
(7)	 Clause 32, page 19 (line 19), at the end of subclause (3), add ", and must also take into account international best practice in relation to radiation protection and nuclear safety".
(8)	 Clause 40, page 23 (after line 16), after subclause (3), insert:
	 (3A)	 As soon as possible after giving directions under subsection (2), the CEO must provide a copy of the directions to the Minister.
	 (3B)	 The Minister must cause a copy of the directions to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the directions have been given.
(9)	 Clause 58, page 32 (lines 9 and 10), omit "the operations of the CEO during that year", substitute:
		 the operations during that year of:
		 (a)	 the CEO; and
		 (b)	 ARPANSA; and
		 (c)	 the Council, the Radiation Health Committee and the Nuclear Safety Committee.
(10)	 Clause 59, page 32 (lines 18 and 19), omit "the operations of the CEO during that quarter", substitute:
		 the operations during that quarter of:
		 (a)	 the CEO; and
		 (b)	 ARPANSA; and
		 (c)	 the Council, the Radiation Health Committee and the Nuclear Safety Committee.
The purpose of the amendments to clauses 14, 16, 20, 23, 31, 32, 40, 58 and 59 is to ensure that the CEO adopts best practice when carrying out his or her statutory obligations under the legislation. This includes being appropriately accountable to parliament for the operations of ARPANSA, the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council and committees, providing that the minister and the CEO consult in relation to appointments to the statutory bodies, and ensuring that the CEO applies the principles of best practice in his or her decision making so that Australia remains a world leader in radiation protection and nuclear safety.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I thank the government for moving all of these amendments together. I commend the government for trying to incorporate the issue of consultation into these amendments. It was certainly one of the criticisms that came out at the Senate inquiry into this bill. When the government talks about consultation before appointing a member to the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council, and when it talks about consultation with environmental and consumer groups, does the government have specific groups in mind and how wide-ranging does the government anticipate those consultations being?

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael

These amendments reflect issues that came out of the committee inquiry. They are certainly improvements to the original legislation and on that basis we will be happy to support them.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—The Democrats will also be supporting the amendments before us, and I am glad that the government has taken into account some of the issues that arose at the Senate committee hearing. In relation to clause 31, which refers to international best practice being taken into account in relation to radiation protection and nuclear safety, exactly how will the government take into account international best practice? Can the parliamentary secretary specify what the government means by that in this amendment?
—The question is that the amend 
 ments be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, against say no; I think the ayes have it.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I understand that we want to speedily resolve this issue, and I appreciate your prowess in putting the question so quickly, but I did have a question before the parliamentary secretary, and I think he was seeking advice. I am certainly not having a go at you but I would like an answer as to whether that or any other amendments are being addressed.
—I will give the parliamentary secretary the opportunity to answer and then I will put the question again.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I appreciate the comment and I appreciate that Senator Stott Despoja did pick up that I was seeking advice. I am advised that we will seek advice on basic benchmarking by international best practice around the world. We will seek advice from other agencies and we will certainly seek to achieve the best possible system.
Amendments agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move Greens (WA) amendments Nos 3, 4, 6, 8 and 15 to 17:
(3)	 Clause 14, page 10 (after line 21), after paragraph (e), insert:
		 (ea)	 to monitor compliance with Division 1 of Part 5 and make recommendations to the Director of Public Prosecutions;
(4)	 Clause 19, page 12 (line 21), at the end of the clause, add:
		 ; (f)	 to report to the CEO on matters relating to radiation protection and nuclear safety.
(6)	 Clause 22, page 13 (line 21), at the end of subclause (1), add:
		 ; (d)	 from time to time, to review national policies, codes and standards in relation to radiation protection to ensure that they continue to substantially reflect world best practice;
		  (e)		 to consult publicly in the development and review of policies, codes and standards in relation to radiation protection.  

(8)	 Clause 25, page 14 (line 27), at the end of subclause (1), add:
		 ; (d)	 to report to the CEO on matters relating to nuclear safety and the safety of controlled facilities.
(15)	 Clause 58, page 32 (after line 12), after subclause (2), insert:
	 (2A)	 The report must include details of any breach of licence conditions by a licensee during the financial year, of which the CEO is aware.
	 (2B)	 The report must include details of all reports received by the CEO during the financial year under paragraph 19(f) or 25(1)(d).
(16)	 Clause 59, page 32 (after line 19), after subclause (1), insert:
	 (1A)	 The report must include details of directions given by the Minister during the quarter under section 15.
	 (1B)	 The report must include details of any breach of licence conditions by a licensee during the quarter, of which the CEO is aware.
	 (1C)	 The report must include details of all reports received by the CEO during the quarter under paragraph 19(f) or 25(1)(d).
	 (1D)	 The report must include a list of all facilities licensed under Part 5 during the quarter.
(17)	 Clause 60, page 33 (after line 3), after subclause (1), insert:
	 (1A)	 If a serious accident or malfunction occurs at a nuclear installation, the CEO must cause a report about the incident to be tabled in each House of the Parliament no later than 3 sitting days after the incident occurs.
This is one of those areas where the outcome of the Senate committee inquiry and the tick-tacking backwards and forwards has led to an improvement in the way the legislation has been put together. So as not to delay this Committee of the Whole unnecessarily, I am happy to say that these amendments relate to the compliance monitoring by the Chief Executive Officer of ARPANSA, arrangements about council and committees, and matters about the accountability and the CEO reporting to Parliament. If I am correct, there is agreement that, in order to speed up the debate, and where there is agreement, I can incorporate the Greens explanation as to why 
 these amendments were necessary. I seek leave to do so.
Leave granted.
The explanation read as follows—
SPEECH NOTES FOR GWA AMENDMENT 3 ON SHEET 1183
CEO TO INITIATE PROSECUTION
Clause 14, p10 after line 21 insert (ea) . . . .
This is an amendment to clarify who has responsibility for initiating a prosecution in the event of the most serious breaches of the Act.
It is essentially technical, rather than a matter of principle.
The offences in Part 5 Division 1 relate toe construction and operation of nuclear facilities and prescribed radiation facilities without a license. We acknowledge that it is highly unlikely that a controlled person might construct a nuclear reactor without a license, however prosecution for failure to comply with the conditions of a facility license or a source license is not such a long shot.
While the prohibitions in Division 1 of Part 5 specify the offences, they make no reference to the process by which such prosecutions would be initiated.
Making it a `Function of the CEO' to monitor compliance and recommend prosecution is consistent with the rest of the Bill which creates the role of the CEO as the main regulatory authority. We think this is what would happen in practice anyway but we believe the CEO needs to be specifically authorised to initiate a prosecution.
It is similar in effect to the granting of powers to the CEO to apply to the Federal Court to obtain injunctions (See Section 42) under various circumstances. It does not make sense for the CEO to be able to seek injunction but not have the authority to refer matters for prosecution.
SPEECH NOTES FOR GWA AMENDMENTS 4, 8 & 15 ON SHEET 1183
REPORTING
Clause 19, p12, line 21 add(f); Clause 25, p14, line 27 add(d); Clause 58, p32 after line 12 insert 2a & 2b.
The purpose of these amendments is to strengthen the reporting requirements in the Bill.
The Bill sets up a Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council, A Radiation Health Committee and a Nuclear Safety Committee. Each of these has the role of advising the CEO on various matters. 

This amendment adds a reporting requirement so that the advice to the CEO is formally recorded and included in the CEO's reports to the Minister. We believe this is important because this may be the only way the Parliament gets to hear of minority or dissenting reports (particularly from the community representatives on the Council or Committees).
This will only happen if there is a requirement on them to report to the CEO and for the CEO to be required to include their reports in the CEO Annual reports referred to in Clause 58.
SPEECH NOTES FOR GWA AMENDMENT 6 ON SHEET 1183
ROLE OF COMMITTEE
Clause 22, p13, line 21, end subclause 2
The Radiation Health Committee is charged with `developing policy' and `drafting policy, codes and standards', but it is equally important for the Committee to review from time to time the existing standards to ensure they meet with world's best practice.
This process of review of policies, codes and standards is one, which we believe should be done in the public sphere. There should be a process for identifying priority areas for review, public notice requirements, consultation periods, draft proposals, publication of drafts and so on.
This will allow the Committee to draw on the widest possible range of sources of advice and give the public greater confidence in the outcomes.
The outcomes will, then, be better policies, codes and standards in the nuclear industry and improved protection from the hazards of radiation.
SPEECH NOTES FOR GWA AMENDMENTS 15 16 & 17 ON SHEET 1183
REPORTING
Clause 58, p32 after line 12; Clause 59, p32 after line 19; Clause 60, p33 after line 3.
These amendments each have the effect of specifying categories of matters about which the CEO is required to report, either annually, quarterly or to Parliament.
In summary they are: any breaches of license; reports received from the Council and committees: directions by the Minister to the CEO; and urgent reporting to Parliament of any accident or malfunction at a nuclear installation.
While we would like to see these matters in the Act, an assurance from the Minister that they would be included in the Regulations would probably suffice.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I advise that the government has agreed to support the proposed amendments from the Greens in relation to clauses 14, 19, 22, 25, 58, 59 and 60. All of these matters were implicit in the bill introduced into parliament. The government is happy to address these issues explicitly.
Amendments agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I move Australian Democrats amendment No. 3:
(3)	 Clause 57, page 32 (lines 3 to 6), omit the clause, substitute:
57 Staff and consultants
	 (1)	 The staff necessary to assist the CEO are to be persons appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922 .
	 (2)	 The CEO has all the powers of or exercisable by, a Secretary under the Public Service Act 1922 , so far as those powers relate to the branch of the Australian Public Service comprising the staff referred to in subsection (1), as if that branch were a separate Department of the Australian Public Service.
	 (3)	 The CEO, on behalf of the Commonwealth, may engage consultants to assist in the performance of any of the CEO's functions.
This amendment relates to the staffing of ARPANSA. It was apparent during the Senate committee inquiry into this piece of legislation that stakeholders are particularly concerned that this agency should be independent. The question of the staffing of the agency was a specific issue for a majority of those people, whether they were community or environmental groups or independent experts present at the committee. We also believe that the staffing of ARPANSA is a vital issue.
If the CEO of the agency relies on the secretary of the department of health for staff, we do not believe it is really credible to claim that the agency is independent of the department. Clearly, the CEO must be able to control the staff of the agency who will ultimately be responsible for the day-to-day work which gives effect to the substance of 
 this legislation. The Democrats were pleased to see that the report of the Senate committee recommended that the CEO be given direct power over the staffing of ARPANSA. I was surprised that this amendment was not one of the government's amendments to this bill, but I am happy to move it on behalf of the Australian Democrats.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —This is important, and the Greens (WA) believe that this is an issue which must be addressed. We are happy to support the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text: —On behalf of the opposition, I indicate that we will support the amendment.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—The amendment provides the CEO of ARPANSA with the power over staffing.
