The government's position is that the bill provides flexibility in staffing and avoids the proliferation of differing industrial relations and other arrangements. It does not affect the independence of the CEO. However, the change to the staffing powers was a recommendation of the Senate committee. While the government does not support such a proposal, it will accept it.
Amendment agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move Greens (WA) amendments Nos 5, 7, 9 to 11, 14 and 18:
(5)	 Clause 20, page 12 (line 29), at the end of subclause (2), add "and in accordance with the prescribed procedures for public consultation".
(7)	 Clause 23, page 14 (line 6), at the end of subclause (2), add "and in accordance with the prescribed procedures for public consultation".
(9)	 Clause 26, page 15 (line 13), at the end of subclause (2), add "and in accordance with the prescribed procedures for public consultation".
(10)	 Page 16 (after line 6), after clause 27, insert:
27A  Public interest disclosures
	 Despite any other provisions of this or any other Act, it is not an offence for a member of the Council or a committee established under this Part to disclose any information about 
 radiation protection and nuclear safety if the person:
		 (a)	 has a genuine concern about an issue relating to radiation protection or nuclear safety; and
		 (b)	 has first discussed his or her concerns with the CEO; and
		 (c)	 believes the disclosure is in the public interest.
(11)	 Clause 28, page 16 (after line 10), before paragraph (a), insert:
		 (aa)	 procedures for public consultation before the appointment of members, including procedures for public nominations;
(14)	 Clause 40, page 23 (line 16), at the end of the penalty, add "for each day during all or part of which the person contravenes this subsection".
(18)	 Clause 79, page 47 (lines 4 to 25), omit "Imprisonment for 2 years" (wherever occurring), substitute "30 penalty units".
The government has indicated that it will not be supporting these amendments, but I will still endeavour to explain them briefly. Amendments Nos 5, 7 and 9 on sheet 1183 relate to prescribed procedures for public consultation. This is still an issue which has not been resolved. It is to give effect to the stated intent of the government following the committee hearing to have a transparent and consultative approach to the appointment of members of the advisory council and committees. By all means, leave the detail to be worked out in the regulations, about which there is still to be further consultation, but let us have this locked in at this stage rather than leave it to the goodwill of the government over the next few months.
Amendment No. 10 relates to public interest disclosures. It is essential that the council and committee structures work effectively. In going onto a council or committee, persons must be responsible to the people to whom they must provide advice (the CEO), to the people who appoint them (in this case the minister), to the rest of council, to the industry which relies on them and, most importantly, to the Australian community who rely on them to be their eyes and ears in the nuclear industry. From time to time—hopefully only rarely—it may be necessary for someone or 
 a number of people in one these councils to break ranks with the orthodoxy of their colleagues.
These committees, honourable senators will remember, are charged with monitoring radiation protection and nuclear safety. There is an obligation to err on the side of caution. We believe that it is necessary to make known concerns so people can make up their own minds and take appropriate action. If someone does have a concern and it is too urgent to wait for the annual or quarterly reports, what can they do? Clearly, they can raise it with the CEO, but more probably they have discussed it at council.
If the concern is genuine and is not shared by the majority or not shared by the CEO, it would be, we believe, in the public interest to disclose it, and this amendment will allow them to do so without fear of prosecution. This is particularly important for the community representatives on the council or committees because they represent a constituency of some kind as well as being council or committee members. The concern may be genuine. The issue has to be first discussed with the CEO and the person must believe the disclosure to be in the public interest. Then and only then can they publicly disclose any information about radiation protection and nuclear safety. If it were not for the culture of secrecy that surrounds and has surrounded this industry, this kind of specific amendment might not be necessary, but there still needs to be a way to move before the communities who have already been associated with industries, such as those associated with ANSTO, can gain that confidence.
Amendment No. 11 relates to public nomination and basically confirms in the bill a commitment given by the government to include in the regulations some process for public consultation before the minister chooses the representatives of the general public or of the community and environmental groups in the case of the committees. It takes that commitment one step further by requiring that the process include some form of nomination from the relevant community. In practice, this could be done by placing an ad in the papers or by contacting relevant local government 
 authorities. How it is done is still a matter for the regulations, but this amendment will ensure that the process of identifying community representatives includes an opportunity for the public to be involved in nominating suitable people. You would not think that would be too difficult.
Amendments Nos 14 and 18 relate to penalties and they highlight an inconsistency in the bill dealing with penalties. Section 40 deals with the power of the CEO to issue directions to a controlled person. There are two occasions on which this applies. The first occasion is where the person is not complying with the act or regulations. When someone is not complying with an act to protect the community from radiation, or when someone is in breach of a regulation about nuclear safety, you might assume that it is a pretty serious matter. Not so, if you go by the penalties of this bill. The second occasion is where the CEO believes a direction is necessary to protect the health and safety of people or to avoid damage to the environment.
The penalties come into play where the CEO's directions are not complied with. Let us consider the seriousness of that. The CEO believes there will be a harm to people if a direction is not carried out. If the person does not carry it out for whatever reason—it is too expensive, it is impractical, tomorrow is a holiday or whatever—what happens next? The penalty is 30 penalty units, which in today's money equates to $3,300. That is hardly a disincentive if the alternative is an expensive upgrade. So then what happens? Under this regime, nothing. There is a power for the CEO to undertake to do those things required if a controlled person will not, but imagine the complications that arise then, not the least being the arguments over cost and who will pay and the difficulty people will have getting information about this at the time.
When we consider that we have a situation where—and we will deal with this in more detail later—a person can be put into prison, according to the government, for two years if they get their warrant wrong, this is way out of proportion. This is an instance where, quite clearly, the community require and need the assurance that there will be some very firm 
 ability to make sure that those people under ARPANSA do feel the necessity to obey the legitimate instructions of the CEO—and this certainly is not good enough.
I do urge the support of the Senate for these amendments. If the government does not support these amendments, I urge the majority of the Senate to see the commonsense in them.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—The Greens have proposed a number of amendments which are unnecessary because of amendments already agreed earlier in this debate. They include Greens amendments to clauses 20, 23, 26 and 28. Other of the Greens amendments would cause significant problems in the operation of the legislation, such as the proposed Greens amendment to clause 27A which proposes that council and committee members may publicly disclose any information that comes before them, including confidential submissions from members of the public and others.
The Greens have also suggested that we change various of the penalty provision under the bill. These have been drafted in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department and are consistent with criminal law policy, where appropriate. The government opposes the proposed amendments to these clauses.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text: —The opposition will not support the proposed amendments. Whilst we recognise and endorse some of the sentiments behind the proposed amendments, we do believe that they, firstly, are unnecessary and, secondly, probably go too far in terms of what is required. We accept otherwise the observations made by the government regarding the current state of the bill dealing with these issues. Accordingly, we are not prepared to support the amendments.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —The Democrats will be supporting the amendments.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I would add just a little in 
 relation to part 7 of the bill, which deals with the powers of inspection; I mention it in relation to nuclear safety inspectors. This is where we have got way out of kilter with what we want the industry to do compared with the precautionary role we think we should be playing in relation to important nuclear health and safety issues. Part 7 of the bill deals with the powers of inspection—inspections crucial to the monitoring of any installation. Unless you can get in and have a look around, you cannot be sure that the information you are being given is the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.
But here, remember that we are hearing from the government and the opposition that it is all right if you hold back on the truth and do not allow the community to get it. Unless they can get in and have a look, basically clause 62 requires the inspector to have either the permission of the occupier of the premises or a warrant before going into a controlled facility. This is reasonable enough, I guess. One would expect that in the normal course of events a warrant would not be necessary but from time to time it might be.
Personally, there are other industries where inspectors, if you have a free and open case of health and safety, would not have to get permission or a warrant; that that would be part of their job. So I am not sure that it is reasonable—let us start off with that. I believe that perhaps there should be the powers of inspection and maybe there should be the powers of spot inspection. So we have already created a problem in relation to the powers of spot inspection.
There could be a part of an installation that an inspector wanted to get to or perhaps something in a facility—a computer simulation in a worst case scenario, for instance—which would require a warrant. There are procedures laid out by which an inspector gets such a warrant and they are, as you would expect, quite thorough. They require an inspector to provide information on oath that it is reasonably necessary to gain access to the premises to see whether the act is being complied with. Well, that is all well and good. 
The problem arises when we come to clause 79, which sets out the penalty for making, in an application or a warrant, a statement known to be false or misleading in a material particular. Yes, it would be naughty for an inspector to spin a yarn or beef up a case for a warrant when there was only suspicion to go on, or exaggerate the credibility of a source or information to get access to check it out.
But are we talking about the kind of offence of an overzealous inspector that could or should lead to a two-year imprisonment, or the kind of offence that might be committed by an inspector who is willing to serve the community in the way the community would be expecting him to which has been brought about by a threat or concern? There are, at worst, offences which led to a bit of inconvenience for the operator of a controlled facility; at best, they could lead to the uncovering of otherwise hidden dangers. Either way, they should not incur a two-year gaol term. Compare the seriousness of this offence with the seriousness of the failure to apply with a safety direction, as I mentioned before, of the chief executive officer—a small fine for a person under the law who does something dangerous compared with the maximum of a two-year gaol term for someone who has an exaggerated concern for safety.
Where are we getting at and why is the Labor Party sitting there, allowing this to happen? The priorities are all wrong here. The more severe penalty should be for unsafe practices, for failing to put dangerous situations right—and not for the safety inspector. We are trying to have the regime administered by ARPANSA to be one that encourages a culture of safety in the nuclear industry. These penalties send the wrong message entirely and have had the effect of putting a muzzle on the inspectors before they even get started.
During the committee, one of the issues raised was: what kind of notice was given in relation to things like the regulations involved that are attached to this legislation? The answer was that there has been substantial consultation in relation to the industry. So, in effect, one of the major industries that we are 
 attempting to regulate in Australia—and that is ANSTO—has been in there, helping to draft the legislation and the regulations. Is it any surprise to anybody that they have written in to have greater penalties for inspectors than for themselves? Of course not.
It is time that the parliament of this place realised that that is not an acceptable practice to be taken by those groups, and we would never accept it under any other circumstances. We realise that, in the Australian situation, we have become, or allowed ourselves to become, dependent on ANSTO for advice on nuclear issues.
This is what we are trying to move away from—to have an independent body. I wonder, with the acting CEO of ARPANSA being in the chamber giving advice to the minister, how independent that has become. We have to start right, and we are not doing that with these kinds of proposals in the legislation.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —The Greens propose to reduce the penalty for inspectors falsely applying for warrants. The provision is included in all legislation whereby such significant powers are provided to individuals such as the Australian Federal Police. The provision simply mirrors the Crimes Act, and I am advised that the penalty for a breach of the legislation can be up to $1.1 million.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—If fraud is covered in the Crimes Act—and I am sure it is—then I am sure the Crimes Act is quite capable of handling fraud. We are dealing with intimidation and, in this case, intimidation should not be written in legislation in respect of people who have a precautionary principle role. They should not be intimidated when they have reasonable concerns. They should not be worried about putting those reasonable concerns on a warrant in case they may have got something wrong or in case a rumour turns out to be incorrect. If I were on an aircraft, would I want somebody to be threatened with imprisonment for following a precautionary principle if a small light indicated that something was not working? Quite frankly, if I were in 
 that aircraft, I would want them to check out the light. Even if they, in every intellectual way, knew nothing was wrong, I would want them to check out the light, and that is what the community would want as well.
Amendments not agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —by leave—In the interests of time, I would like the strong support of those amendments to be registered from the Greens (WA).
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—by leave—I move Democrats amendments Nos 1 to 9:
(1)	 Clause 20, page 12 (line 29), at the end of subclause (2), add "and on the basis of merit".
(2)	 Clause 20, page 13 (line 3), after "member", insert "except in accordance with a code of practice determined under section 28A and".
(3)	 Clause 20, page 13 (after line 9), at the end of the clause, add:
	 (7)	 In making appointments, the Minister must ensure that the balance of interests on the Council is such that no one interest may dominate the Council or derogate from its independence.
(4)	 Clause 23, page 14 (line 6), at the end of subclause (2), add "and on the basis of merit".
(5)	 Clause 23, page 14 (line 9), after "member", insert "except in accordance with a code of practice determined under section 28A and".
(6)	 Clause 23, page 14 (after line 15), at the end of the clause, add:
	 (7)	 In making appointments, the CEO must ensure that the balance of interests on the Committee is such that no one interest may dominate the Committee or derogate from its independence.
(7)	 Clause 26, page 15 (line 13), at the end of subclause (2), add "and on the basis of merit".
(8)	 Clause 26, page 15 (after line 20), after subclause (4), insert:
	 (4A)	 The CEO must not appoint a person as a member except in accordance with a code of practice determined under section 28A.
(8)	 Clause 26, page 15 (after line 24), at the end of the clause, add:
	 (7)	 In making appointments, the CEO must ensure that the balance of interests on the Committee is such that no one interest 
 may dominate the Committee or derogate from its independence.
(9)	 Page 16 (after line 14), at the end of Part 4, add:
28A  Procedure for appointment of members
	 (1)	 The Minister must by writing determine a code of practice for the appointment of members of the Council and of committees established under this Part that:
		 (a)	 sets out general principles on which appointments of members are to be made, including, but not limited to:
			 (i)	 merit; and
			 (ii)	 independent scrutiny of appointments; and
			 (iii)	 probity; and
			 (iv)	 openness and transparency; and
		 (b)	 sets out how these principles are to be applied to the selection of members.
	 (2)	 After determining a code of practice under subsection (1), the Minister must publish the code in the Gazette .
	 (3)	 The code of practice has effect accordingly.
	 (4)	 Not later than every third anniversary after a code of practice has been determined, the Minister must review the code.
	 (5)	 In reviewing a code of practice, the Minister must invite the public to comment on the code.
	 (6)	 A code of practice determined under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .
These amendments, as I explained in my speech in the second reading debate, relate to accountability and transparency. They are not unlike amendments that the Democrats move on a number of occasions where boards such as this are involved. As I noted in my speech, Senator Andrew Murray, who is the Democrats accountability spokesperson, most recently moved similar amendments to the operation of the Wheat Marketing Board. It is part of our concern that we restore faith in governments, our boards and the parliamentary processes for the community, and that means appointments are not to be based on mateship or nepotism but directly and only on merit.
I cited in the second reading debate the experiences of the United Kingdom and its 
 Nolan committee, which has also sought to overhaul and redress ministerial and other appointments in the UK. It is something that the Democrats have sought to do a number of times here in Australia. We will continue to move amendments of this nature.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text: —On behalf of the opposition, I indicate that we will not be supporting the amendments. As Senator Stott Despoja correctly pointed out, this is a fairly standard set of amendments that have been moved on a number of occasions by the Democrats, particularly Senator Murray, in respect of other legislation. We have outlined on previous occasions our reasons for not supporting amendments, and on this occasion we will adopt the same approach.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—We have taken note of the comments made by Senator Stott Despoja. However, the government does not support the Democrats' proposed amendments to clauses 20, 23, 26 and at the end of part 4.
These amendments are twofold. Firstly, they provide that a member of the council or committees should not be appointed except in accordance with the code of practice under section 28A, which describes a very complex procedure. Secondly, the amendments require the minister or the CEO to ensure there is a balance of interests on the council and the committees, and that no single interest dominates these bodies. I understand that the Democrats are on a crusade to try to control government appointments from the Senate. The government will not be supporting the Democrats' proposal to establish this complex and unnecessary vetting system.
The government amendments moved earlier in this debate ensure there will be appropriate consultation before the appointment of any members to the council or committees. However, anything that moves beyond this mechanism usurps the legitimate right of the government of the day to make its own decisions regarding appointments and to be accountable for them.
With regard to clause 20—as I referred earlier in relation to this block of amendments proposed by the Democrats—the government believes that the proposed amendment to clause 20 undermines the legitimate right of the government of the day to appoint members to advisory bodies such as these. The government is, of course, committed to consulting appropriately and has demonstrated this by including relevant provision in the legislation. In respect of clause 23, the Democrats are proposing the same procedure for the appointment of committee members as they proposed for the council. The government opposes these changes on exactly the same grounds.
With regard to clause 26, the Democrats are proposing the same procedure for appointment of committee members as they proposed for the council. Again, the government opposes these changes on the same grounds. At the end of part 4, the Democrats are proposing the insertion of an additional section, which describes procedures for appointments of members as previously discussed. As the government does not support the proposal in relation to this appointment process, it does not support this further amendment either.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I thank the opposition and the government for outlining their reasons for rejecting the Democrat amendments. I express my disappointment that they are not willing to support amendments which we see as providing clarity, transparency and accountability. If the parliamentary secretary believes that we are on some kind of crusade, well so be it. I suppose the Democrats are associated with keeping various groups and parties honest, if you like. We see it as still very much a part of our mandate, to use that oft bandied around word. The government talks about a legitimate right to make appointments and says that the government should be accountable for those appointments. That is exactly what we are suggesting—that there be increased mechanisms that ensure that governments are accountable for those appointments and that they explain those appointments.
The government's reference to the procedure for the appointment of members and its dismissal of that is quite discouraging. While it may be claimed that it is a complex process, the general principles that we outlined on which appointments can be made include merit, independent scrutiny of appointments, probity, and openness and transparency. I hardly think that those principles are incredibly challenging for any government. We simply seek to enshrine not only in this legislation but in other legislation these very general and appropriate principles which we believe would be to the benefit of any organisation. If you have a system of appointment on principles of merit, independent scrutiny probity, and openness and transparency, those principles are to the benefit of any organisation. I express again my disappointment that the amendments have been rejected by both parties.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The Greens (WA) will be supporting the Democrats' amendments.
Amendments not agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —by leave—I wish to have recorded, in the interests of time, the fact that the Democrats moved those amendments and voted for them and our disappointment that they were lost.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move Greens (WA) amendments Nos 12 and 13:
(12)	 Clause 31, page 19 (line 4), omit "The CEO", substitute "Subject to this section, the CEO".
(13)	 Clause 31, page 19 (after line 11), at the end of the clause, add:
	 (4)	 The CEO must not issue a licence to a controlled person to construct or decommission a nuclear installation unless all of the following steps have occurred:
		 (a)	 the Minister has caused to be established in the prescribed form a public inquiry into the need for the construction or decommissioning of the nuclear installation;
		 (b)	 the public inquiry recommends that the construction of or decommissioning of the nuclear installation is necessary; 

		 (c)	 an environmental impact assessment of the proposed construction of decommissioning of the nuclear installation has been undertaken;
		 (d)	 the environmental impact assessment concludes that the construction or decommissioning of the nuclear installation is unlikely to have a significant, adverse environmental impact.
	 (5)	 The environmental impact assessment mentioned in subsection (4) is to be undertaken in accordance with the procedures set out in the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 .
These amendments go to the heart of accountability in relation to new installations. Clause 31 empowers the Chief Executive Officer of ARPANSA to license a nuclear installation. In order for this to be anything like acceptable to the Greens, there need to be some changes. For indications of community concern about nuclear issues you only have to look at what has come up recently in the public eye and the level of concern that was unleashed by the video last week outlining the plans of a private company, Pangea, to turn Australia into the world's waste dump for high level nuclear waste.
I saw an article today in the West Australian newspaper regarding Hendy Cowan, the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, who did speak to representatives from Pangea. When I read his words very carefully I realised that they did not actually rule out Australia accepting nuclear waste from other countries' nuclear power stations or imply that he was against that. We are talking about enriched uranium or reactor cores. What he said was that it would be difficult for Australia to accept nuclear waste from countries to which we had not supplied uranium. When you translate that, it means that the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, a National Party Deputy Premier, has said that it would be reasonable—and I am paraphrasing here—for Australia to take nuclear waste from reactors from other countries so long as we have supplied the uranium. That leaves us pretty open. He is saying that if we have exported uranium we should be prepared to accept the nuclear waste.
So whilst we have had various statements from the federal minister saying what we will not do, when you scratch a little deeper about what has or hasn't been said at the state level, we are not looking at a fantasy scenario; we are hearing in the public arena the Deputy Premier of Western Australia say that nuclear waste would not be acceptable if we have not exported the uranium. How much uranium has Australia supplied over time? What does that potentially mean in terms of sheer volume of high level and medium level nuclear waste, including plutonium, enriched reactor cores and so on? What does that mean in terms of what could happen in the future?
The community wants some say in regard to scrutiny in the nuclear industry—for example, the existing research reactor at Lucas Heights. We have noticed that the minister never answered that question from Senator Brown about the new technology being researched there. Even in the context of this current bill, how can they have that confidence when we know there is that wave of secrecy over here? There was no advertising in relation to the Senate committee on this bill because it was a short committee. We were able to get a number of people to express concerns.
The amendments recognise that the community is interested—and has a legitimate interest—when any new installation is being considered. If you do not think the community of Australia is interested, just try any community in Australia and say: `By the way, you are going to make lots and lots of money out of being an international waste dump' and see what happens.
As the bill stands at the moment, the CEO of ARPANSA can licence a new nuclear installation with a minimum of fuss. This is clearly not sufficient. It is especially not sufficient when you consider that the definition of a nuclear installation includes a number of issues like nuclear reactors, nuclear filled storage facilities and nuclear filled fabrication plants.
We would like to see the strictest possible licensing and monitoring regime to make sure that it is as safe as it can possibly be. This amendment seeks to put commonsense pre 
 conditions into the legislation so that licensing is not seen as some sort of short circuit, a quick and dirty way of getting nuclear installations authorised. This amendment seeks to ensure that the stages have been gone through before the licensing process starts. It is carefully constructed so that it does not involve the CEO in policy matters about whether there should be this or that installation. It does not involve the CEO at all in any of the matters which should be the subject of public debate. It simply says that the CEO must not issue a licence unless the minister has set up such an inquiry and the need has been demonstrated.
At that stage, the normal environmental impact assessment process cuts in, and if there is not likely to be a significant adverse environmental impact then the CEO can proceed with the licence process. The effect of this will be to stop the issue of a licence unless the minister has set up an inquiry into the need for the installation. If there is a need, there is an environmental impact assessment, and it is unlikely to have adverse impact. Some of this includes matters which may well be the province of other legislation, especially the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. However, the need for the inquiry is new.
It should probably go into the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998. In the absence of current legislation, the only way to ensure such an inquiry is done is to have it referred as a prerequisite to licensing in the ARPANSA bill. I urge the Senate to support these amendments. I indicate in advance that we will seek to divide on this issue, because quite frankly we do not know where the Senate stands on this issue, and it is important to put it on the record.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text:
—The opposition will support amendments Nos 12 and 13 moved by Senator Margetts. We have an amendment on the running sheet which substantially seeks to do the same thing—that is, to ensure that there is a process in this legislation whereby any  decision to construct a major nuclear installation would be the subject of a public inquiry or an independent inquiry.
In our amendment we proposed that the Chief Executive Officer of ARPANSA would not be permitted to issue a licence pursuant to this section unless, firstly, the CEO had obtained from the minister a certificate in the minister's opinion having regard to the objects of the act that there was a need for the nuclear installation and, further, such certificate must not be issued unless there was either an independent inquiry or a public inquiry pursuant to section 11 of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Senator Margetts has put forward a proposition which certainly has the same intended result but which is in a different form. Whilst there are some subtle differences between the two, the end result is the same as that which we have been seeking to achieve.
The need for this is self-evident. Anybody who understands what is happening within the nuclear industry in this country today recognises that the government has made a decision to build a new nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights to replace the current HIFAR reactor due to be decommissioned in about 2003. The government has made that decision without any proper consideration of the views of the scientific community, the medical community or the wider community, particularly the community of the surrounding areas of the Sutherland shire.
I appreciate that there is a major debate as to whether or not Australia needs another nuclear research reactor. The Labor Party has made it clear that that is a matter still to be properly resolved. There are arguments for and against the proposition. For instance, it is argued that we should have another reactor to replace HIFAR; that the best place and the cheapest place to put it is where the current reactor is; that it has a value with respect to the manufacture of medical radio isotopes; and that it is in Australia's national interest. That is a very brief potted summary of those who support the proposition.
There are some within ANSTO, I would suggest, who support the proposition simply because it means that ANSTO as an organisation will continue in perpetuity into the future. It guarantees they have another reactor to operate and, consequently, a large injection 
 well in excess of $400 million or $500 million of public funding over the next 40 years. The argument that we should have one because we already have one is one that some people support, notwithstanding what the merits of the case might be.
There are arguments from people within the local community who believe that, if we are going to have another nuclear reactor in this country, it should be located well away from any suburban residential area. The area around Lucas Heights is not the same as it was 40 years ago, when the establishment was built. It is no longer remote bushland some reasonable distance or long distance away from the city of Sydney. It is within about three to four kilometres of a thriving, growing part of the Sydney metropolitan region, with a population in excess of 150,000. If there was not a nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights today, no government in its right mind would contemplate putting one in that location. The fact that there is already one there is not of itself a reason why it is the best site for a reactor in the future.
I wanted to particularly address my remarks to the issue of why we need a public inquiry process. The 1993 Research Reactor Review, the McKinnon review, which I have referred to earlier in this debate, concluded that there were a range of issues that should be resolved before any positive decision for the new reactor was made. I quote from the conclusions of the report. It said:
If, at the end of a further period of about five years,
. a high level waste site has been firmly identified and work started on proving its suitability
. there is no evidence that spallation technology can economically offer as much as or more than a new reactor
. there has been no practical initiation of a cyclotron anywhere worldwide to produce technetium-99m
. there is good evidence of strong and diverse applications of neutron scattering capability in Australian science, including many young scientists, and a complex of industrial uses
. the national interest remains a high priority
it would be appropriate to make a positive decision on a new reactor. The most suitable site would need to be identified. 

If any one of these onerous requirements is not met, either a negative decision, or a decision to delay further, would be indicated.
That was the report of the Research Reactor Review issued in August 1993. What that report said was that, if any of those very onerous conditions were not met within five years—it is appropriately just on five years since that report was handed down—a decision should not be made to build a new reactor or, at the very least, it should be delayed. But this government ignored the recommendations and conclusions of the McKinnon review. It made a decision to build a new reactor at Lucas Heights. In one of the most cynical political exercises I have ever witnessed, it announced that decision on the very day that it announced to the community of the Sutherland Shire and southern Sydney that it was not going to build the proposed airport at Holsworthy. It was a bit of good news, bad news. As I said, it was a highly cynical approach.
Efforts to obtain information from this government as to what alternative sites were being considered by the government have been refused on the grounds of cabinet confidentiality. There has been no proper assessment made, as Professor McKinnon called for in his report, about the value of alternative technologies such as spallation technology. There has certainly been no decision made about the suitability of any site to take high level waste.
The report recognises, despite what ANSTO might say and despite what the government might say, that there is high level waste stored at Lucas Heights. Recent proposals by the government to ship that waste overseas have come to nought because of decisions made in Dounreay in Scotland that they are not prepared to take that waste. So there is clearly a major gap to be filled in terms of what is ultimately going to be the approach adopted in dealing with the waste currently stored at Lucas Heights.
Frankly, the position we have is that this government has proceeded to make decisions contrary to the recommendations of that very thorough inquiry and has done it in a most cynical way with minimal consultation with 
 local government bodies in the area and the community generally. It is a major decision to build another nuclear reactor in this country. Whatever one's view—whether one supports it or does not—it is appropriate that it be subject to the most vigorous scrutiny, and not just by an environmental impact statement.
Frankly, most people have absolutely no faith in environmental impact statements anymore. We all know that about 99 per cent of proposals subject to an EIS eventually get approved. People have very little faith in the process that has been undertaken for the EIS to this point in time. It has been subject to very severe criticism by the Sutherland Shire Council and internationally recognised consultants they have engaged. It has been subject to severe criticism by Environment Australia itself.
For instance, there is no design for the new reactor even on the table at the present time. So one wonders how an EIS could be properly conducted. But, in any event, there still needs to be a proper public inquiry before any such decision is made. We believe that such a major issue involving the expenditure of $500 million or more which commits this nation and particularly that area to the existence of another reactor for the next 40 years, on top of the decommissioning of the existing reactors, is such a serious issue that it should be considered by a public inquiry.
These things do not come along every day of the week. That is what the provisions of the Environment Protection Act are specifically there for—that is, section 11 for the conduct of public inquiries. I am advised that there have only been some four inquiries conducted under that act since it was enacted. At least two of those related to most serious issues. The very first one was the Ranger inquiry conducted by Justice Fox, known as the Fox inquiry. The second one was the inquiry into sandmining on Fraser Island. Both of those are major issues of environmental significance, public health and safety significance and so on. We believe this is a similar case.
The issue has been raised as to the potential for major waste reprocessing facilities. We are 
 very disappointed with the attitude the government adopted in respect of an earlier amendment. We support very strongly the proposals contained in the Greens (WA) amendments. As I said, they reflect the intention of our amendment; that is, before any major nuclear installation, such as a new reactor at Lucas Heights or any others that may be contemplated—we hope they will not be—it should be subject to the most thorough scrutiny, including provisions for a public inquiry. We support the amendments.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—On behalf of the Democrats, I support the amendments moved by the Greens (WA). For many of the reasons outlined by Senators Forshaw and Margetts, the Democrats support these amendments. We believe that the concept of needs assessment is a particularly positive one, as are the environmental impact assessments that are often undertaken.
Our concerns have been on record for a long time now about the concept of a new nuclear reactor, not a replacement reactor, at Lucas Heights. For that reason, my party is opposing that particular reactor for a number of reasons, apart from environmental and health hazards—lack of community consultation, not to mention lack of scientific consultation. This is also the single biggest amount of money ever allocated from the Australian science budget. I believe it was done so with minimal—negligible—consultation with the chief scientist.
Our views are very much on record. I look forward to hearing from other senators in this place—from opposition as well as government senators—as the debate rages further as to what their views are when it comes to the Lucas Heights reactor. We certainly support the amendments before the chair.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—The Greens (WA) amendments propose that a new and additional process of public inquiry be instigated which must demonstrate the need for a nuclear installation before the CEO makes any licensing decision for that installa 
 tion. The first point to make is that the purpose of the bill is to provide for the safety of nuclear facilities and use of radiation when the government and the community have decided that such facilities are needed.
This legislation is not the place to try to change the ways in which proposals are assessed and proceed. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act still applies, and it can be expected that any substantial proposal would invoke the procedures under this act. Further, as was the case with the proposed replacement research reactor at Lucas Heights, substantial proposals for nuclear facilities will be assessed over a period of time in ways in which the government of the day considers appropriate. Second, it is clear that the real purpose of these amendments, and those proposed by the ALP, is to delay the replacement research reactor project.
Whilst I noted Senator Forshaw's comments—and I know his particular personal residential interest and genuine interest as a New South Wales senator—it is also important to note the comments of the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Gareth Evans, on 11 May 1998 when, in correspondence, he said, on the new reactor: 
I am afraid that the realities of politics in an election year, and in particular our need to win Hughes, have led us to a position of opposing a new reactor at the Lucas Heights site—as difficult that may be to justify in objective safety-focused terms.
I also note the degree of cynicism in many of Senator Forshaw's comments. This project has been assessed exhaustively, including through the Australian Science and Technology Engineering Council inquiry in 1992, the McKinnon report into the need for a replacement reactor in 1993, the current environmental impact statement and the current Senate Economic References Committee inquiry. The government absolutely refuses to implement a further resource intensive, wasteful process, which is nothing more than an underhand attempt by opposition parties to further delay key government initiatives.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I do not wish to delay this 
 debate more than is necessary. The minister said when the `government and the community' deems it necessary. Quite clearly, from what Senator Forshaw said, that has not been proved. The McKinnon report said exactly that it was necessary to establish the need, and that has not been established. The government has not done it. None of the processes that have taken place have done it. It is not an accountable process. There is a lot of money involved in this, apart from anything else. We are dealing with community health and safety, which cannot and should not be rushed in terms of that.
If there has been no demonstrated need, why are we getting into it, except that some people involved with ANSTO think this is the way for Australia to be involved in the international fora on nuclear issues. That is not good enough, Minister. It is not good enough to make a decision on this basis. How dare we point at India and Pakistan and say, `Your argument that you want to be considered part of the international community is irrelevant.' We are doing the same thing here—even the concept that Australia should be contemplating continuing to have a nuclear reactor because we get to sit in on the international atomic debates!
We are pointing the finger at India and Pakistan saying, `Don't continue your nuclear testing. This is not going to make you an important nation.' But we are doing the same thing in Australia by continuing to have some form of nuclear reactor because that gives us a seat at the table with the big guys. It is ridiculous. It is puerile, and it is not the basis upon which we should get into it when there is no demonstrated need.
	 Question put:
	 That the amendments (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—by leave—On behalf of the Democrats, I move amendments Nos 1 and 2:
(1)	 Clause 31, page 19 (line 4), omit "The CEO", substitute "Subject to this section, the CEO".
(2)	 Clause 31, page 19 (after line 11), at the end of the clause, add:
	 (4)	 The CEO must not issue a licence to a controlled person that authorises persons to do some or all of the things referred to in subsection 29(1) in connection with a 
 nuclear waste storage or disposal facility operated for commercial purposes.
	 (5)	 It is the intention of the Parliament that subsection (4) has effect to the extent possible under the Constitution.
These amendments relate to the issuing of licences. I mentioned in my speech during the second reading debate that we, like all members in this place—and I suspect a number of people in the community—were quite concerned to see that recent promotional video that was produced by Pangea Resources nominating Australia as the best country in the world to store high level nuclear waste.
We were also disturbed by the assertions by members of that organisation that they had had meetings with ministers. Again I acknowledge that federal ministers in this government have not been involved in those meetings. Certainly, we had an assurance from Senator Nick Minchin in question time when the Democrats asked questions about this issue. The statement given by the minister was unequivocal. He said:
. . . no high level radioactive waste facility is planned for Australia and the government has absolutely no intention of accepting the radioactive waste of other countries.
The Democrats welcomed that assertion by the government and the minister and, of course, his further claim that government policy was clear on this and that it would not be changed. I indicated that we would be seeking to enshrine this commitment in legislation. That is the purpose behind these amendments—essentially, to protect members of the community from the harms associated with any commercial nuclear waste disposal facility. I commend the amendments to the chamber.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I seek a little point of clarification—and perhaps the parliamentary secretary can make a clear and unequivocal comment. If Australia sells uranium to another country and that uranium is used in the nuclear cycle, say, in a nuclear reactor, is the radioactive waste from that reactor the waste of another country or could it technically be considered the waste created by Australia?
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—With regard to the comment just raised by Senator Margetts, I am advised that it is the waste of another country. With regard to comments made by Senator Stott Despoja, the Democrats' amendments provide that the CEO must not issue a facility licence in connection with a nuclear waste storage or disposal facility operated for commercial purposes. The purpose of this bill is to regulate all Commonwealth radiation and nuclear activities. The issue whether an activity is commercial or not is completely irrelevant. Further, the meaning of the term `commercial' is not defined and could be expected to impinge on the government's capacity to appropriately recover the costs associated with, for example, any waste repository.
By opposing the amendments, the government is ensuring that, regardless of the commercial footing of any activity, it will be controlled and regulated—a significant improvement on the current situation. I also wish to reiterate Senator Minchin's comments in this chamber that it is not government policy and will not be government policy to accept radioactive waste from other countries.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I thank the parliamentary secretary for reiterating the government's policy. I also thank him for outlining why he will not be supporting the amendments, although I understand that we have revised and changed these amendments in order to ensure that there are no constitutional difficulties with these amendments. I understand that subclause (5) of amendment No. 2 in relation to clause 31 has that intention in mind.
So there are no constitutional impediments to agreeing to such amendments. Given that the parliamentary secretary has taken this opportunity to reiterate the government's commitment to its current policy, wouldn't this be a wonderful and exciting opportunity for the government to enshrine that in legislation?
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text: —I have a further question for the parliamentary secretary. If the government opposes these amendments, is it leaving the door open, for instance, for the Pangea proposal to be ultimately approved if there is a change in government policy?
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I reiterate the comments of both Senator Hill and Senator Minchin in the last week or so. Both have given unequivocal commitments of the government. Senator Hill said:
. . . the government is under no pressure; furthermore, it is not intending to build a facility for the disposal of high-level nuclear waste.
And Senator Minchin said in answer to a question:
. . . I think going back before we came into government—on the general issue of radioactive waste management, but those discussions have always been clearly on the premise that it is not government policy and will not be government policy to accept radioactive waste from other countries nor to accept high level radioactive waste.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Most people obviously wanted to get those kinds of assurances. However, we did get similar assurances on the GST. When is `never', `never ever', `will not' or `won't ever'? We know there are times when policies change. The Australian Democrats are asking—and I am supporting this—if `ever', `never ever' or `won't be' ever changes to `will', `maybe' or `well circumstances have changed'—and that does happen, we know it does; we have seen it happen with the GST—then there will need to be a change in the legislation. That is not unreasonable.
Why the government would not accept that, if they were going to change that major policy area they would have to make a change to legislation, I do not know—except that they want to leave that door open. And that is exactly what they are doing. The public will see it as a door left open by leaving this unclear in the legislation.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I do not mean to 
 delay the Senate but I do not believe that Senator Forshaw's question was answered specifically. I do not think Senator Forshaw feels that it was answered specifically—I do not know what the head nodding means. The government has reiterated a commitment not to make Australia a nuclear waste dump. I am wondering whether the parliamentary secretary could answer specifically: would this leave the door open? I am interested in the legal implications of this amendment being defeated. Does it not allow those commercial dumps, if you like, to come into this country? I am just wondering whether it leaves the door open legally—not whether or not the government has a particular policy at this stage because, as Senator Margetts has stated, that can be changed pretty much at the whim of government.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text:
—I indicate on behalf of the opposition that we support Senator Stott Despoja's amendments. Whilst it is very gratifying to have the assurance of the parliamentary secretary on government policy, he has not responded to the question. I took it that he did not intend to respond because it is either a yes or a no. In the absence of saying no, the answer must be yes. We do not think that is good enough and we will support the amendments.
—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former Tasmanian senator, Brian Archer. I welcome you to Canberra.
	 Question put:
	 That the amendments (Senator Stott Despoja's ) be agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text:
—I move opposition amendment No. 1:
(1)	 Page 19 (after line 11), after clause 31, insert:
31A Minister to issue certificate
(1)	 The CEO must not issue a licence under section 31 for a nuclear installation unless the CEO has obtained from the Minister a certificate that, in the Minister's opinion, having regard to the objects of this Act, there is a need for the nuclear installation.
(2)	 The Minister must not issue a certificate under subsection (1) without first causing to be held: 

	 (a)	 an independent inquiry into the need for the nuclear installation; or
	 (b)	 a public inquiry under section 11 of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 .
(3)	 In this section:
 independent public inquiry  means an inquiry undertaken by persons who:
		 (a)	 in the Minister's opinion possess appropriate qualifications to undertake the inquiry; and
		 (b)	 include one or more persons who are not employed by the Department of State administered by the Minister, or a related Commonwealth authority, and have not, in the 5 years immediately before the commencement of this Act, provided services to the Department or the authority under, or in connection, with a contract.
I do not need to go through all the arguments. They were put in respect of the Greens amendment earlier.
While I am on my feet, I wish to respond to a rather cheap shot from Senator Tambling. It was something to do with declaring a residential interest. Everyone in this chamber knows that I happen to live within a reasonable proximity of the Lucas Heights reactor. If I need to declare that again, I will. I invite him and all the other honourable senators opposite to declare their residential interest, which is that they do not want the nuclear reactor in their backyard.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move two amendments to the Labor Party amendment:
(1)	 After paragraph 31A(2)(a), omit "or", substitute "and".
(2)	 Paragraph 31A(2)(b), before "a public inquiry", insert "if the independent inquiry recommends that the nuclear installation is necessary,".
These are simple amendments. They include the category of decommissioning amongst those areas which should receive full assessment and consultation. Basically, they are an extension to the categories included in the ALP's amendment. I am pleased to see that the ALP seems to think that is acceptable. It originally had just the provision of a new reactor facility. We have agreed that the 
 decommissioning is a major event and must be done with great care and consultation, so an inquiry should be involved in it. I am happy to support opposition amendment No. 1 with the Greens (WA) amendment Nos 1 and 2.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—The Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendments.
Amendments (by Senator Margetts) not agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Forshaw) not agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text:
—by leave—In the interests of concluding this matter, we do not seek to divide. However, I record our support for the amendment.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (LICENCE CHARGES) BILL 1998
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998
Bills agreed to.
Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 reported with amendments; Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Licence Charges) Bill 1998 and Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998 reported without amendment; report adopted.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —by leave—I indicate that the government is not opposed to the principle of the motion. The government believes the inquiry should commence following the release of the second Sherman report, and the government would be happy for the inquiry to be held next sitting.

name: Cook, Sen Peter
text: —by leave—I note the remarks of the government. I will seek an opportunity between now and the next sitting of the Senate to confer with them about the detail of what that might mean and, on the basis of that discussion, consider recommitting the motion.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—It may have been thought from comments that I have made over recent weeks that I have some sort of opposition to the health funds in the private health system. I have some questions about them, as I have questions about the public health system, but I am not ideologically opposed to the dual system, provided it is fair and properly run. I am becoming less confident in the funds as a result of their inane campaign which was run recently. I am less confident in their capabilities. But, because it is usual to do so, I need to declare that I am a member of a health fund and have been for 40 years. I understand how people feel when they are struggling on a very insufficient income to try to keep up the payments—even then it was difficult.
Let me come to the package of legislation itself. The rebate proposal does not go far enough to meet sound public policy requirements. There is no evidence by any modelling that has been presented to us that that proposed rebate will work and achieve the objectives of the government; in other words, there are no guarantees that it will work. There are no guarantees that premiums will not rise—in fact, we have heard that premiums will rise next year. There are no guarantees that the rebate will not get gobbled up in the payment of extra costs created by specialist doctors, operating on private patients in private or, indeed, in public hospitals.
There are no guarantees about anything, except that 70 per cent of the taxpayers of Australia will contribute to delivering an amount of $5.4 billion to assist the other 30 per cent of the population who are privately insured—though I suppose 100 per cent, if you like, will do that, rather than the 70 per cent. There are no guarantees that the 30 per cent rebate will result in the eradication of extra medical fees beyond the insured costs—those medical out-of-pocket expenses which are very much the concern of fund members.
Honourable senators will know from their own experience that the two major complaints of fund members are the ever increasing premiums and the extra charges in costs they are hit with once, after having been in hospital, they get home. Once they get home, in 
 come the bills, one after the other; it also might be that even three or four months later a bill comes in. Multiple medical fees not only are aggravating but also leave many patients with onerous bills.
This legislation does nothing to address this problem. Many of the elderly who are treated in private hospitals could be cared for in other more suitable settings, such as convalescence and rehabilitation services. The coordination of better health care services should be associated with a measure like the one that is before us today, the rebate. Then health insurance could be more user friendly, particularly for the elderly and chronically ill.
There are no guarantees that health funds will not continue to raise their premiums after the introduction of this package of legislation containing this rebate. This begs the question of whether the rebate is in the interests of the members or administration of the funds. The government has not been able to encourage health funds and doctors to strike effective arrangements to eliminate out-of-pocket fees and set premiums. There are some examples of where this has been achieved, and honourable senators during debate have been informed of those by various government senators—and I acknowledge that.
The government maintains that the rebate will help reduce public hospital waiting lists; yet there is no guarantee that this will occur. In fact, there is no guarantee that privately insured patients will not enter public hospitals; they have that right. And I guess that, if nothing is done about the gap, there will be more and more privately insured people—that is, members of health funds—going into public hospitals so as to avoid those out-of-pocket expenses. At the same time low income elderly people who cannot afford insurance are resigned to waiting on public hospital lists for treatment. The government should seriously consider instigating a special program to meet these needs.
Madam Acting Deputy President, I must say that I stand before you in a somewhat difficult situation. The speech I have given thus far was going to come to certain conclusions which perhaps do not reflect discussions that have taken place today. I point out again that 
 the government—and I have indicated this previously—should seriously consider instigating a special program to meet the needs of low income elderly people who cannot afford insurance, including their need to have quicker access to hospital and other health services. It is conceivable that such a program, conducted along with a rebate scheme, could reduce public hospital demand and better meet the needs of the elderly in particular.
The government should consider some way to ensure that health funds move towards the elimination of gaps. I will move an amendment, which is currently being drafted, to go some way towards that particular objective—and I apologise to honourable senators that that is not as yet ready to be distributed. It is a simple amendment that will give an incentive to health insurance funds to come to agreements with hospitals and doctors for that purpose.
There should be an attempt to address the burden of unknown medical fees, so the proposal I am going to present to the Senate will include the not known aspect. For many patients, procedures are performed on them not knowing what the gap is, not knowing that it will cost far more than what Medicare provides or what their health insurance funds provide.
I must say that we are extremely fortunate that Australia is blessed with a highly qualified and dedicated medical profession. I appreciate that private health care has developed under a fee-for-service system. I also appreciate the value of the doctor-patient relationship and its intimate role in quality health care. However, it is incumbent upon the medical profession to understand that the lack of attractiveness of health insurance also rests with some of their number charging unreasonable fees.
I understand that there are no easy answers to these problems. However, the solution proposed by the government in this legislation does not go far enough—it needs to go further. A 30 per cent rebate for the purchase of health insurance has merit if it is associated with other tangible measures which will alleviate the demand on public hospitals, do something practicable for the health of the 
 elderly and lead to the elimination of out-of-pocket expenses, out-of-pocket fees.
I have concerns that the elderly, particularly the chronically ill, need a better coordination of their services, and their complex needs must have greater attention from our general practitioners. I am particularly concerned that low income, uninsured elderly people have little choice but to wait on the public sector lists for urgent care. We need to do more to ensure access for them to services in both hospitals and convalescent home care.
I am particularly perturbed by the lack of progress on out-of-pocket expenses and believe a more concerted effort by government and the private health sector is needed. The rebate proposals need to be advanced only if real reforms on these other measures are actively progressed. I do hope that, during the course of this debate, there will be an indication by the government of precisely that. At this stage, I am prepared to support the bill into the committee stage.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—At the outset, let me declare a personal interest of 37 years of holding private health insurance. At the same time, let me also reflect on the last 10 months. As many of my colleagues in this place will know, I had heart surgery in August and that required extensive financial support and obligation from many people, and I appreciate their assistance. There were eight specialists, two GPs, many pathologists, X-Rays, echocardiograms, angiograms, et cetera. But in financial terms, at the end of the day, my 10 months has cost $30,378. It is very important to note that the health insurance contribution to that was $21,284; Medicare, $7,135; and the gap, to which Senator Harradine has just referred, $1,959. In all, some 134 services were rendered to me in the course of this year, and it is very important to note that principal of $21,284 met by my private health insurers that otherwise would have been met by the public purse, and without the degree of choice that I did enjoy under the circumstances I had.
The government is committed to maintaining a balance between public and private 
 sector health so that Australians have a choice when it comes to health care that is fair, affordable, customer-friendly and good value for money. The  Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998  and related bills allow for all members of private health funds to be eligible for a rebate of 30 per cent of the cost of their health insurance contributions. For example, a family with an annual health insurance contribution of $2,000 will be  entitled to a rebate of $600. This policy was taken to the recent election by the Howard government and roundly endorsed.
It is ironic that, after two decades of seeking to keep the bastards honest, the Australian Democrats are now seeking to prevent the government from honouring this commitment. They have lost their perspective of what honesty is all about and have become captives of political bastardry themselves. It is also ironic to see the Australian Labor Party carping on about gaps and billing for private health insurance, after spending 13 years doing nothing. Talk about political hypocrisy. The ALP have shown their hand as nothing but poker card players.
The Australian Private Hospital Association has said that without private hospitals the public system would have to treat an extra 1.8 million patients per year, perform twice as much surgery as now, provide 23,000 more beds and require $3.5 billion extra funding every year. If private health insurance participation declines further, the public system will have to provide more and more of the services and care that the private sector is providing. The ALP and the Democrats have conspired to wipe out that great Australian value of individual choice from the people they purport to represent.
The current trend shows that private health insurance will decline to around 20 per cent by the end of the current Australian health care agreement. This dreadful scenario would cost the government an additional $2.5 billion over the life of these agreements. Even more damaging to the bottom line is the fact that the base for the new agreements would be $5 billion more than the current agreements.
The alternative being offered by the coalition is to support choice, support quality care 
 and support private health care to continue the balanced health system that has served Australia so well. It is important that we note the issues that have been raised in this debate, particularly those that have been raised this evening by Senator Harradine. The government has undeniably done more to reduce the incidence of medical gap fees than any other government. I know that Minister Wooldridge is currently embarked on a major campaign with a number of issues to advance that important area.
Senator Crossin got it very wrong the other evening about the Northern Territory. She did not focus on the impact of this legislation on people who live in rural and remote parts of Australia. This is one of the most important tenets of this legislation. There is so much that needs to be offered for all of these people to get the balance right. People who come from rural and remote areas often need access to special services, not in their own area but in other areas. They need the reimbursement that private health insurance can offer to so many of them. And those people living in the bush are not rich.
The constitution of Australia prohibits any government's control of doctors' fees. However, through encouraging negotiation and partnerships between doctors and hospitals and health funds we have produced the first successes ever achieved in this area, for which Dr Wooldridge can take the credit. Legislation has been introduced to allow health funds, hospitals and doctors to negotiate over the entire medical fee, including any charges above the medical benefits schedule. The promotion of simplified billing has been a major lever in changing the culture of doctors, who are now recognising the importance of providing a better service to their patients. Labor did nothing during their 13 years to address the gaps. We certainly have, and some of the initiatives proposed by Senator Harradine tonight will go a long way in that regard.
I acknowledge that more needs to be done. We will continue to work hard to promote these issues, despite the moaning and the carping of those opposite. In summary, these bills provide for sensible incentives to com 
 plement recent and upcoming structural reform. The government's 30 per cent rebate makes sense economically, supports the choice that is one of the strengths of the great Australian health system and is expected by the Australian electorate.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—I seek leave to make a brief statement on the interests of certain senators in relation to this legislation.
Leave granted.
—I thank the Senate. To expedite debate on the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 , I wish to inform the chamber, at the request of my colleagues and before the second reading of the bill, that the following Labor senators hold private health insurance: Senators O'Brien, West, Bishop, Hogg, Ray, Forshaw, Conroy, McKiernan, Schacht, Bolkus, Collins, Crowley, Gibbs, Cooney, George Campbell, Lundy, Mackay, Crossin, Reynolds and me. I invite the Senate to accept this as a suitable form of declaration of interest for the purpose of its consideration of the private health insurance bills.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —by leave—I declare my interest as a long-term holder of private health insurance and one who doesn't expect the community to pay further for my subsidy.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —by leave—Madam Acting Deputy President, with your leave, I think I should indicate that those who are known to me on the government side to hold private health insurance are: Senators Hill, Alston, Newman, Minchin, Vanstone, Herron, Kemp, Ellison, I. Macdonald, Campbell, Troeth, Tambling, Boswell, Calvert, Coonan, Patterson, Heffernan, Abetz, Knowles, Parer, Ferguson, Watson, Synon, Gibson, Payne, S. Macdonald, MacGibbon, Eggleston, Tierney, Crane, Lightfoot, McGauran and Brownhill. I have not been able to ascertain any interest in respect of Senator Chapman, who is overseas.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—I am afraid I have not got the information in front of me as to which of my colleagues are in private health insurance. I shall ask them to let us know individually before the end of the evening.
Sitting suspended from 6.28 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —Just prior to the recess, Senator Faulkner and I read a number of names into the Hansard  record of respective senators from our sides who had private health insurance. I omitted in reading the list from this side to include Senator Reid, the President of the Senate. I would appreciate it if that could be added to the record.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—I wish to read onto the record the Democrat senators who have an interest in this issue. The following senators have private health insurance: Senator Bartlett, Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Woodley, Senator Bourne and Senator Murray, who pays two families private health insurance—his own family and his parents' family.
	 Question put:
	 That the amendment (Senator Lees's ) be agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
	 "and that the following matter be referred to the Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report by the last sitting day in November, 1999:
	 Australia's health system, with particular reference to the issues outlined in Recommendation 22 of the Industry Commission's report on its inquiry into the Private Health Insurance Industry (Report No. 57, February 1997)".
I move this motion for a proper inquiry, as was called for by the majority of people giving evidence.
Question resolved in the negative.
	 Question put:
	 That these bills be now read a second time.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—by leave—I move Democrat amendments Nos 1, 2 and 4:
(1)	 Page 6 (after line 11), after clause 4-5, insert:
4-6 Income test, policies covering only one person
	 (1)	 If the policy covers only one person, the income test is satisfied in respect of the financial year in question if the sum of the taxable incomes of all of the persons whose incomes are required by subsection (2) to be taken into account is less than 
 the maximum amount under subsection (4).
		 Note:	 For taxable income, see section 4-8.
	 (2)	 The persons whose incomes are to be taken into account are:
		 (a)	 if the person covered by the policy is not a *dependent child during the financial year—that person and the *partner (if any) of that person; or
		 (b)	 if the person covered by the policy is a dependent child at any time during that year—any *parent of that person, and the partner (if any) of the parent, but only if, in respect of that year:
		 (i)	 the parent, or his or her partner, made one or more payments of premiums in respect of the policy; or
		 (ii)	 a person (other than a parent of the dependent child or the partner (if any) of that parent) made one or more such payments, under an arrangement entered into with the parent or partner.
	 (3)	 For the purposes of subsection (2), a person is the *partner of another person only if, on the last day of the financial year, the person is the partner of that person.
	 (4)	 The maximum amount is:
		 (a)	 if at all times during the financial year the person covered by the policy is not a *dependent child and is not the *partner of another person—$30,000; or
