		 (b)	 if at any time during the financial year the person covered by the policy is not a dependent child and is the partner of another person—$50,000; or
		 (c)	 if at any time during the financial year the person covered by the policy is a dependent child—$50,000.
4-7  Income test—policies covering more than one person
	 (1)	 If the policy covers more than one person, the income test is satisfied in respect of the financial year in question if the sum of the taxable incomes of all of the persons whose incomes are required by subsection (2) to be taken into account is less than the maximum amount under subsection (4)
		 Note:	 For taxable income, see section 4-8.
	 (2)	 The persons whose incomes are to be taken into account are:
		 (a)	 each person covered by the policy who is not a *dependent child during the financial year; and 

		 (b)	 the *partner (if any) of each such person; and
		 (c)	 if all of the persons covered by the policy are dependent children at any time during that year—any *parent of any of the persons covered, and the partner (if any) of the parent, but only if, in respect of that year:
			 (i)	 the parent, or his or her partner, made one or more payments of premiums in respect of the policy; or
			 (ii)	 a person (other than a parent of the dependent child or the partner (if any) of that parent) made one or more such payments, under an arrangement entered into with the parent or partner.
	 (3)	 For the purposes of subsection (2), a person is the *partner of another person only if, on the last day of the financial year, the person is the partner of that person.
	 (4)	 The maximum amount is:
		 (a)	 if the persons covered by the policy do not include 2 or more *dependent children at any time during the financial year concerned—$50,000; or
		 (b)	 if, at any time during the financial year, 2 or more dependent children are covered by the policy—the amount worked out as follows:
	 $50,000 + ($3,000 x (Number of dependent children—1))
	 Example:	 If the policy covers the members of a family that has 3 dependent children, the maximum amount under subsection (4) is:
	 $50,000 + ($3,000 X (3—1)) = $56,000
4-8  Meaning of taxable income
	 In section 4-6 or 4-7:
	 taxable income , in relation to a person, means the person's taxable income, within the meaning of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 , for the financial year in question, and includes any share in the net income of a trust estate:
		 (a)	 to which the person is presently entitled as a beneficiary; and
		 (b)	 in respect of which the trustee of the trust estate in that capacity is liable to be assessed under section 98 of that Act; and
		 (c)	 that is attributable to that financial year.
(2)	 Clause 10-5, page 18 (after line 6), before paragraph (a), insert: 

		 (aa)	 you satisfy the income test under section 4-6 or 4-7 (whichever is applicable) in respect of that year; and
(4)	 Clause 4-5, page 6 (lines 4 to 8), omit subclause (1), substitute:
	 (1)	 You are entitled to a payment under this Chapter if:
		 (a)	 you have paid, or your employer as a *fringe benefit for you has paid, a premium under an *appropriate private health insurance policy for the whole or a part of the financial year that began on 1 July 1998 or a later financial year; and
		 (b)	 you satisfy the income test under section 4-6 or 4-7 (whichever is applicable) in respect of that year;
Most of these issues were covered fairly thoroughly as we went through the second reading stage. We must reach some reasonable compromise on this legislation. It would be the Democrats' preference that we did not support private health through this mechanism, but this is one the government has chosen so we will try to make the best we possibly can out of it. By means testing this in this way would mean that roughly half of this extraordinary amount of money, about $1½ billion a year on average, would be able to be directed into the public system. At least if we could not make the government put it into the public system, we would actually make a reasonable saving so that hopefully, when it came to budget time, their consciences would dictate that that money be directed into things such as the dental health program, rural health and public hospital waiting lists.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—I want to make a contribution at the beginning of the committee stage of this debate about the way the committee stage is to be handled. I think a number of senators, certainly opposition senators, would have noticed that Senator Herron, who is the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, apparently is not going to handle the committee stage of this debate. Perhaps Senator Tambling can indicate whether he is going to handle it for the government. Senator Tambling, the parliamentary secretary, nods. So I assume that means he is going to 
 handle this. I think this is a very concerning development indeed.
—It is not concerning that Senator Tambling is handling it.
—No. Senator Ray, if you would allow me the courtesy—
—Senator Ray, if you would cease interjecting and, Senator Faulkner, if you would address the chair.
—Thank you for your protection, Madam Chairman. This is a serious issue. Who could forget over the last few weeks of sitting of the Senate the contributions that Senator Herron has made in question time in this chamber, attempting to answer serious questions about the issue of health insurance and a number of other issues relating to the health and aged care portfolio? We have heard Senator Herron time and time again attempt to outline what he believes is the government's position in relation to this important issue, and a range of others, to be proved comprehensively that he has a total incapacity to deal with issues of substance in the chamber.
Today we saw what could only be described as a completely incoherent performance from Senator Herron. It is not as if Senator Herron has an awful lot of work to do. It is not as if he has got an enormous ministerial load. This is the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs who has not had responsibility for the issue of stolen children, who has not had responsibility for the native title debate, who now does not have responsibility for the issue of reconciliation, because that is now, as a result of the new ministerial arrangements, in the hands of Mr Ruddock, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. This is the minister who cannot come in at the committee stage of this debate and deal with this issue on which he has been the spokesperson in this chamber.
Regardless of any other commitments that he might have, the truth of the matter is that this is a very important piece of legislation, the responsibility of the minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, and Senator Herron does not have the capacity to 
 deal with the detail of this legislation or the focus that is required of a minister during a committee stage debate. And, as far as the opposition is concerned, it is absolutely unacceptable, for a committee stage debate on legislation that the government believes is as important as this, that the minister representing the minister for health in this chamber cannot front up to the Senate and handle the committee stage debate on behalf of the government.
That says it all. It is not just that he cannot handle himself during question time on the range of issues on which he has had questions asked of him not only by opposition senators but also by minor party senators and Senator Harradine, it is not just that he cannot go the hard yards in question time, but that, here in this important and crucial committee stage debate, Senator Herron is missing in action. The point I want to make is that that is not good enough. We have had Senator Herron plead for the representational responsibilities that were previously handled by Senator Newman, whose approach always on these issues was to say, `I don't know anything about it. I will just refer it to the minister in the other chamber.' Senator Herron's approach is to say the first thing that comes into his head, and it is normally nonsense. It is normally incoherent psychobabble.
I think it is important that the record shows that in this committee stage debate, which the government claims is of such significance on such an important issue, the minister representing the minister for health cannot front up after lecturing senators, the parliament and the people of Australia day in and day out during the parliamentary sittings since the election. He cannot be bothered or is not interested enough to come in and handle this committee stage debate in the parliament.
Senator Tambling, as the parliamentary secretary, is doing this job and, obviously, he is struggling with the detail. I do not expect Senator Tambling to have the same level of familiarity with this particular issue. No reasonable person would expect Senator Tambling to be able to take over this responsibility in the chamber at short notice and handle the debate when, of course, you have 
 got the minister representing the minister for health squibbing it.
—Senator, please do not reflect upon ministers.
—I think we have had enough of lectures from Senator Herron, the sort of flaky performances that we have seen from him in question time today and over the last few weeks. I think that if Senator Herron wants to have the responsibility of a minister representing, then he ought to come in and do the job. This is a disgraceful performance in relation to the handling of this bill in the committee stage, and Senator Herron and the government stand condemned for it.

name: Ray, Sen Robert
text:
—I will not delay the committee long, but I still want to add a couple of points, to which Senator Faulkner has alluded, before we get to the substance. The attitude of the opposition is that if  Senator Herron wants to get up day in and day out and lecture us on how important this bill is—and there is no doubt he has done that in the past—he really should be here to handle it. I am pleased Senator Faulkner put it in such a way as not to reflect on Senator Tambling. What is Senator Tambling's position? He is a parliamentary secretary, who does not get 1c more for all the work he does, and he does a lot of work. He gets one medium-level adviser and one receptionist and, if he is lucky, he might get a DLO.
Meanwhile, we have another minister working in his second job as Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, getting $50,000, about seven staff and about 100,000 platitudes and cliches a year, yet he is not here to handle this bill—the only bill that he will probably have of any complexity or of any importance between now and when he gets appointed High Commissioner to London or to wherever he is heading off.
This is starting to become a bit of a pattern. I do not mind the fact that parliamentary secretaries are used as workhorses. But, really, they are not the front-line troops; they are the reserves, they fill in the gaps, and you should not expect them to take on the responsibility of shepherding through very complex 
 legislation, given the poor resource base and the lack of remuneration. What parliamentary secretaries are getting is all responsibility and nothing else.
It is true that some people may see the taking of a parliamentary secretaryship as a way up the greasy pole—that is, you do your apprenticeship as a parliamentary secretary and you might eventually be promoted into the role of minister and eventually to cabinet. I think that is true to a point. I am not going to point to anyone that disproves it because there are always hurtful examples on any side of the chamber at any particular point in time.
When it comes to crucial legislation—and I suppose the coalition would put this as one of its four or five centrepiece pieces of legislation in its three-year term; no doubt the GST would be their key one, but I would have thought this one would be in the top five of the remaining ones—we do not have Senator Herron here today. Why don't we? He may have a genuine excuse for not being here today, but, if he did not, I suspect he still would not be allocated the handling of these bills. You have got a minister who the Prime Minister picked, frankly, because he was a friend and he liked the look of him. That is basically why he was made a minister, the same as Mrs Moylan was in Western Australia. That mistake was rectified.
—How did you get one?
—It is hard to understand, Senator Ferguson, why you did not get a berth. I absolutely concede that. It is almost impossible to conceive—no, hold on; you don't meet some of the criteria: you are not vacuous and you probably have a grasp of detail. If you could give that up, we might see you on the front bench. You might be a regular feature there.
—You are ruining my preselection.
—Don't provoke me because I know we have got an important debate to get on with. But I really think, as a matter of principle, on the key piece of legislation in the health area for the next three years, the person who asks for the job of representing health in this chamber should be 
 here to put it through. It is no reflection on Senator Tambling. In fact, I think he will do a much better job of handling this. I am not trying to embarrass him in this way, but he will do a better job than Senator Herron. But, Senator Tambling, so would a telephone pole, so do not get too keen on that particular analogy.
—For the benefit of honourable senators, can I say that there is no running sheet for these bills. There is sheet 1215, which is the five Australian Democrats amendments, and there is sheet 1221, which is Senator Harradine's six amendments. I think it is fairly straightforward to work through the Democrats amendments and then Senator Harradine's amendments, which is the way I would plan to proceed.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I wish to clarify one point with Senator Lees. When she started speaking to the amendments on sheet 1215, she drew attention to amendments Nos 1, 2 and 4. Am I right in assuming that her initial comments were in respect of amendment No. 1?

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text: —I was mainly speaking about amendment No. 1, yes. But if you look down further at amendment No. 2, you look further at the actual income test and other details that are needed. If you go down further, amendment No. 4 is further entitlement relating to the means test.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I appreciate that. However, the initial comments were with regard to the first amendment. The critical issue that the senator is raising in these amendments is that the government's private health insurance rebate should be means tested. I have no doubt that this rebate is the most equitable way to encourage people who can afford to take out private health insurance and to reward those who already have it. I completely reject the proposal by the Democrats that the rebate should be means tested. The government will not be 
 doing any deals to compromise the integrity of this policy.
Australia's private health insurance system complements our universal health care system and funds around 80 per cent of all private hospital care. It is entirely reasonable for those people who choose to fund part of their own private care to get back part of the funding from the public system they would otherwise draw on. The rebate is in essence a tax concession designed to reflect the extra cost burden borne by people across all income levels for private health insurance which is not carried by others who rely solely on the public system.
The government decided not to means test the rebate for several reasons. Firstly, the universal nature of the rebate reflects the universal nature of Medicare. Every taxpayer pays the Medicare levy whether or not the taxpayer uses it. It is only fair that every taxpayer who chooses to pay extra for private health insurance is entitled to the rebate.
Secondly, means testing the rebate would have an adverse impact on increasing private health insurance membership—the government's main objective in offering the rebate. The largest falls in health insurance participation rates have been in the middle to high income bracket and these people are generally lower risk members who are essential to balancing the cost of sicker members and helping control the escalating costs of premiums. The limited success of the current Private Health Insurance Incentives Scheme illustrates the likely effect means testing would have on the success of the 30 per cent rebate.
Thirdly, the universality of the rebate recognises that, for some people, private health insurance is the only way they can be assured of a reasonable level of choice. For example, in rural communities, although publicly funded services are available, private health insurance provides a wider range of health care choices, especially if their condition requires transfer to a metropolitan facility. I certainly referred to that when I talked about my own personal health experience this year. I am not trying to transpose myself as someone special. I appreciate that there are 
 many other people in lower income levels than me who would similarly draw on that area.
The government supports people's right to choose between Medicare and private health care services. It is essential that people making the choice to choose private health care are treated equally, just as Medicare users are.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text: —It is a good opportunity with the parliamentary secretary referring to his own experience earlier this year—and I say thank goodness he is looking so healthy—to ask if he can tell us, in regard to the $30,000 or so expenditure that was required for that heart operation procedure, what the cost would have been in the public health system. If I remember correctly, the parliamentary secretary Senator Tambling said in his case some $21,000 was covered by insurance, $7,000 or so was covered by Medicare and the rest was out of pocket. That gives a very clear measure of the costs of this procedure with private insurance available. I would like to know what would have been the cost had the same procedure been undertaken in the public health arena and whether it would have been as readily and quickly available?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I can only reflect on my personal experience in this area. As I said, that $21,000 that was contributed by my personal health insurance certainly reflected the extra costs of a number of specialists. It was largely the component of the health provisions at the private hospital of my choice and included all of the special facilities that were made available, such as intensive care and specialist treatment.
If I had not elected to have that surgery in Sydney, then I would have had to have been evacuated from the Northern Territory to Adelaide into the system where the cost would then have been borne by taxpayers. I assume it would have been at a similar cost factoring, but it certainly would have cost substantially more because of the extra requirements that would have had to have been imposed on the government for that provision, particularly with regard to the transport costs. 
 Again, I would not have had the choice of specialists—some eight of them—who were required to administer to me. I would have had no choice in that regard. I would have naturally been a public patient in Adelaide.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—This is a very important point. If I can remove it from the personal arena, I would like to get from the government what the actual costs would have been both for the medical procedures involved—all of them—and separately for the transport because that is another matter. When it comes to people who do not have the income level that we senators have, such things as availability of air transport become much more problematic. Access to the diagnostic services of specialists themselves also becomes much more problematic.
 There is great concern in the community that, if you join an insurance scheme, the price of the procedure goes up. At all levels there is a premium that is taken by the private system which makes it much less attractive for people to take out insurance. That is one of the major factors why we are seeing the tumbling participation rate in private health insurance.
 What I would like the government to do—if you cannot do it now, I would like an assurance that the work can be done on this—is to give a cost comparison for a very expensive medical procedure (one that has been very successful, very important and, I daresay, lifesaving) as against what it would have cost in the public health system. It is important that we get a measure on these things so that we see the premium, the mark-up, that occurs once you move across into the private system.
If the government has figures to show what the premium is for the delivery of a private health service—we are talking about legislation which is going to put billions of dollars over the years into supporting that health service and therefore that premium—I think the public needs to know the facts of the matter. Here is a very good example that, due to the grace of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, we have before the committee. It will serve the purpose of this exercise—seeing what the difference is between the costs in the public 
 arena and the costs once you take out insurance and move into the private health arena.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —The important issue to be addressed here is the particular matter in the legislation before us, and I would draw all senators' attention back to that. I would merely make the point with regard to the personal example that the fact that I chose private health insurance means that there were no costs on the public sector—costs which would have been borne if I were in that alternative health care service.

name: Crowley, Sen Rosemary
text:
—That is a very curious claim because the public sector, Medicare, covers the large part of your health costs up to the medical benefits schedule fee. Indeed, I do believe that what was previously 75 per cent cover went to 100 per cent some time ago—maybe I am not right on that. No adviser is nodding; perhaps you can check whether that is right. A very significant part of your health care cost was borne by the public sector. That needs to be clearly put on the table.
 I rise to ask not about your health but about this matter in general. As a doctor myself, I have long since learnt that you never ask or never talk about other people's health in the public arena. If you wish to talk about your own, that is fine. I do not know what operation you had—and I do not want to know—or what procedures you had. I would like to talk about this in the general.
In the course of my second reading contribution, I said that I would like to know what is the state of play of casemix. Is the department still working in the area of casemix? Can the department say what happened to casemix, if you are not continuing with it? It was understood that an effort was being made to try to put a cost on a surgical procedure or a procedure, and therefore you would be able to say that this cost should be more or less the same in the public or the private sector.
It is curious to me that any surgical procedure, any operation—according to much of the evidence of people who have to pay the gap—costs more in the private sector when the private sector does not have anything like 
 the add-on costs that the public sector has. If there were to be a case for a more costly procedure, it ought to be in the public sector where our large public hospitals carry the burden—happily—of educating our doctors, educating our nurses, educating our pathologists and educating all sorts of health professionals. Very often they carry the burden of providing ancillary costs such as pathology in times past and morgues—whatever else was necessary for an adequate and thorough delivery of comprehensive health care.
What people were trying to do in casemix, as I understand it, was to factor out those extra costs from the cost of the procedure so that we could have a more accurate understanding of the comparison between procedures in one sector and another. I ask the parliamentary secretary for an answer on what is the state of play of that kind of study. Is it continuing and, if so, can you give us some comparative costs?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I believe that it would be much more appropriate for Senator Crowley to raise these issues in the next round of Senate estimates. Estimates is much more relevant to the issues that she raises.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—This is highly relevant. This is what we are actually dealing with. We are dealing with a huge amount of money that you want to throw at the private sector without checks and balances and even the knowledge of what procedures really cost there. We know that the government does not have these figures. That is why they cannot supply them. It just further adds to our argument that we should not be dealing with this partially blindfolded, which is what the government wants.
I return to some comments Senator Tambling made about how we have to have this because we have to acknowledge that all Australians, if they are earning, pay taxes and Medicare. I want to pick up on the point that Senator Crowley just made. A lot of the costs were covered by Medicare. A lot of the costs that someone who goes into the private 
 system has are covered by Medicare. People need Medicare to go to their GPs. They tap into the public system when they get a prescription or have radiology or pathology tests. The issue is that you do not get  anything back at the moment for the bed. That is the way in which I believe, if we want to support private hospitals—and we certainly should be—we can support them. It would cost a fraction of this measure.
If the right checks and balances are put in place, we might tackle some of the other difficulties we have in the private sector. At the moment, there are no cost controls there. This is the battle the Labor Party fought when it brought in the contracting system, which fell into a hole because doctors said, `How dare you interfere with the doctor-patient relationship.' They wanted to charge what they liked. We had no right to know what they were charging.
I stress here and acknowledge that we are only talking about a minority of doctors. But the problem for the pensioners is knowing which doctor will come out of the hat and how much they are eventually going to end up with. Certainly speaking for doctors in my home state, I congratulate particularly those working at places such as Ashford in the private system, who seem to be able to manage with the Medicare rebate and the schedule fee. People do not get gap payments with them. However, you only have to go through our mail and the calls we get to know that, unfortunately, there are a lot of different doctors out there. I had better not mention particular specialties here tonight.
It is highly relevant to this bill that we have no cost controls on the private system. This money could simply be going to further feed those doctors who want to charge more. They know now that their patients are getting money back for their private health insurance. So I argue that some of the constraints that may have been there may be lifted. Again, it is a minority of doctors, but they give the private system an incredibly bad name. They are ones that the private hospitals do not have any control over. The funds also do not have any control over them.
I understand what Senator Harradine is trying to do. However, this is where the second part of his amendments fall down. If we are going tonight to put in restrictions on gaps and make the funds pay them, all the doctors will do for some of them is charge the absolute earth. I imagine that it will drive premiums up—I will ask these questions later—between seven and 10 per cent to be able to guarantee that there are no gaps. Tonight we are giving a 30 per cent rebate. We will see these funds increase their charges by eight or so per cent next year. Add on 10 per cent for the gaps. Where are we then? We are almost back to square one, and we could put $1.5 billion into the public system.

name: Crowley, Sen Rosemary
text: —I thank Senator Lees for her comments, which I think make my case very nicely. Senator Tambling's answer was, `Why don't you ask those questions in estimates.' I will tell him why. If he does not have the answer now, what is he going to do between now and estimates? If we are at least going to get some kind of answer, that is encouraging. But my question is exactly pertinent to the bill before us. Indeed, I signalled during my speech on the second reading debate, which happened to be some days ago, that I would be asking this question. Here now or later—I do not really care—I think it is pertinent for the department to provide to Senator Tambling and for him to provide to the Senate some evidence about the relativities of these costs. Does it cost more to have the same surgical procedure in the private sector? If so, why?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I will draw the senator's comments to the minister's attention and ensure that she receives the information she seeks.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—I would like to add a couple more questions to the list. I am looking at some of the information that came to us during the committee process. Another concern in the private system—this has some real basis in fact—is that certain procedures are available there far 
 more regularly than they are in the public system. One example is caesarean delivery. Women who go into the public system have a quite small chance of having a caesarean compared with women who end up in a private hospital. Rather than there being any overservicing in the private system, there may be underservicing in the public system. So, whichever is true, we need some answers. I put on notice this question for the minister: what have you done to actually look at the level of servicing in the private system? If we tonight put measures on gaps without some of these checks and balances, all that that small percentage of doctors will do is order more procedures.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—What we have heard in the last few minutes very well illustrates why what we should have done as a parliament, and what I believe we should still do, is have a full inquiry into health care funding and the whole kit and caboodle of what is going right or wrong. There is a lot of hairy-chested stuff being put by the government; I am not referring to anybody in this chamber. Basically, in the public arena, there is a lot of stuff going on which is based on a lack of proper knowledge. This relates to the lack of a proper inquiry into the issues involved in health funding.
We have had inquiries into health insurance but not a proper inquiry into health funding and the issues concerning gaps, for example. How are they created? Will anything we could do tonight within this legislation really and honestly deal with that situation? I do not think it is possible simply by concentrating on health insurance. That is why, from my point of view, as I mentioned in my speech on the second  reading debate, I have difficulty passing amendments at this stage which in effect give legitimacy to a policy direction based on private health insurance products. In fact, the overwhelming evidence in the committee was that this was not the way to proceed.

name: Crowley, Sen Rosemary
text:
—I have a question to ask—I am sure I know what the answer will be but let me ask it anyhow. Parliamentary secretary, is 
 there a cost differential between a surgical procedure done in a public hospital on a public patient and the same procedure done in a public hospital on a private patient? We are looking at the relativities between a private patient in a private hospital and a public patient in a public hospital. As we know, one of the reasons that there is considerable strain on our public hospital system is that so many private patients are having their procedures done as private patients in a public hospital. Indeed, very often it is as a public patient in a public hospital.
—As is their right.
—Indeed. It is also the right of the private patient. You will be pleased to know that very few public patients have the opportunity to be treated as public patients in private hospitals. That was tried by the previous Labor government and, with rare exceptions, the doctors did not want to operate on public patients in private hospitals because they were unable to charge above the medical benefit schedule. Senator Lees reports well of Ashford Hospital in our state but it was not the case when the doctors in South Australia refused to operate and use the spare beds in the private sector some years ago, when they could have run down the waiting lists in the public hospitals.
I congratulate the doctors in the Illawarra region who did contribute, through the private sector, to reducing the pension waiting lists for eye operations. Is the parliamentary secretary going to continue to tell us tonight that he does not have any detail, and come back some other day, when tonight we are supposed to be voting on the expenditure of $1.7 billion of precious taxpayer dollars—
—Year after year.
—Exactly. It may not be that figure because, if the government's proposal is that more people take up private insurance, and it is an open-ended cheque for 30 per cent for everybody's private health cover, that figure will be even more. I would like to know what the government puts as a guess on that. Before we get to that question, can the parliamentary secretary give us an answer to the first question: is the cost of an appendix operation or an open heart operation 
 in a public hospital different for patients who are public patients and patients who are private patients.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I can only vouch for one open heart operation and that was in a private hospital. The issues that have been raised this evening I think are better placed in other committees and other considerations of this parliament. I can assure you that the Minister for Health and Aged Care is actively pursuing all of the areas and all of the issues that have been canvassed. What we are dealing with tonight is legislation that is to provide a private health insurance rebate and the effects of that. Whilst I appreciate that Senator Crowley and Senator Margetts, and to a certain extent Senator Lees, are coming at this matter from a philosophical point of view on which we probably do have major differences of opinion, I draw their attention back to the actual legislation and its effects. That is the purpose of our being here tonight.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Just briefly, I am basing my opinion on the evidence—not on a philosophical or ideological position but on the basis of the evidence that has been presented to us and to the people who were sitting on that committee on Friday. Nobody could justify the direction that the government is taking. The figures were not there, the models were not there, and even the health department people there had a lot of difficulty explaining the report that supposedly they had written. The reality is that my opinion is not based on a philosophical point of view, it is that there is no evidence to back up your claims—you have presented no evidence to back up your claims. The parliamentary secretary presented his own situation but the questions relating to the comparisons have not been answered. That is because they cannot be answered to support these claims.

name: Crowley, Sen Rosemary
text:
—The response from the parliamentary secretary is not disappointing: it is shameful. I think the points made by my colleagues are absolutely critical. The govern 
 ment is not providing any hard data for us, and that is really a disgrace.
—I ask Senator Crowley to be very careful.
—It was a disgrace, no person was a disgrace. I understand the finer distinctions here. I think it is appalling that we are being asked to vote on the expenditure of this amount of money and the government is unable to provide the critical data for us. The evidence, again and again, is from the people who write to us and say, `I have done the right thing. I have paid for my private health insurance for 10, 30, 40 years. I have finally had to use it and what do I have? No protection against health costs but a huge bill.'
I will not labour this any more. It is late and people want to get on. I am glad that the parliamentary secretary can speak of one operation in the private sector, but I would hate that to be taken that there is no good standing for such procedures to be done in the public sector. The majority of open heart operations are done in the public sector. The patients who have had them are walking, talking and recovering beautifully and they are not out of pocket one cent.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—Mr Temporary Chairman, you will be relieved to know that I do not intend discussing Senator Tambling's medical conditions except to say that the only point of interest that came out of Senator Tambling's example of his medical experiences is that from now on, if this bill is passed, the taxpayers of Australia will be helping to fund his private health insurance. They will be subsidising his taxation by about $800 a year because he will be paying less tax because he is in private health insurance. He will be $800 better off and we will be contributing $800 for a rebate for Senator Tambling's health insurance, or something of that order, because we will be paying 30 per cent off his private health insurance. For someone who is on a salary of $80,000 per year, I think that is a national disgrace.
I do not think people earning $20,000 or $30,000 a year ought to have to subsidise 
 Senator Tambling's private health insurance. He talks about choice and I agree with him that he has the choice to take it out but we have the choice not to pay for it for him. That is what this debate is about. It is about who pays for Senator Tambling's health insurance and who pays for John Howard's health insurance. I am happy for them to have health insurance but they should pay for it themselves. The taxpayers of Australia should not pay for their health insurance. They have the means and the wherewithal to make that decision and pay for it themselves.
The bill tonight says, `All of you out there in Australia who pay taxes, whether you are on $18,000, $25,000, $30,0000 or $40,000 a year, have kids and are struggling, your taxes will go into a pool so $1.5 billion can be paid to prop up the private health insurance of people who choose to take it out.' We are not talking about the money going in to prop up the private health insurance of the battlers; $900 million of this goes to people earning over $70,000 a year. The vast bulk of it goes to the top end of town. It goes to the Senator Tamblings and John Howards of Australia. This is a disgrace. The government will learn to regret this decision because it is inequitable. It is unfair.
Every time someone on a waiting list at a public hospital rings you up and says, `I can't get into hospital—why?' tell them it is because the money is paying Senator Tambling's private health insurance instead. That is why. That $1 billion plus that could end waiting lists in this country and that could mean that nobody waits in pain to go into hospital for an operation could be used so they would not have to wait, so they would get their operation in the public hospital and they would not be in pain. It could be used so pensioners who cannot eat because their teeth are broken could get their teeth fixed. But no, what are we saying tonight? We are saying the priority of the parliament of this country in health care is to subsidise Senator Tambling's and Mr Howard's private health insurance so they can pay less for their private health insurance. That is what this is about. It is a priority.
Whether we choose to spend $1.5 billion on this or on something else is the conscious choice of this parliament. We decide tonight whether this is a good use of $1.5 billion. I say it is not a good use and, when the 70 per cent of Australians who are not in private health insurance understand what this means—understand what it means for public health, understand what it means for waiting lists, understand what it means for nurses' wages, understand what it means for services in public hospitals—they will turn on this government.
Also, the 30 per cent who pay will begin to realise. The government has been very clever at trying to convince the 30 per cent who are in private health insurance that this is all about them, but they have to understand that for the vast majority of them this is a very marginal increase. The current scheme provides them with up to $450. Most of them will get, at best, around $600 to $700 out of this. It is a marginal increase. This money is going to the top end of town. That is what this is about. The government says we have to get the young rich people back into the scheme. That may be right, but do we have to pay to get them back in?
On John Howard's salary of $200,000 a year, he gets a tax discount of $2,000 because he does not pay the one per cent surcharge. So he pays $2,000 less tax than he otherwise would and we are also going to throw in $700 to $800 worth of rebate. So we are going to pay $2,800 to $2,900 of public subsidy so John Howard can take out $3,000 worth of health insurance. We are going to pay 95 per cent of John Howard's and Senator Tambling's health insurance. Why? Can't they afford it? I reckon they can afford it. We would be better off spending the money on helping the pensioners waiting to get their hips replaced so they can have an operation in a public hospital. I think that is a much better use of the money.
If the government want to defend this move, they have to say to Australians why this is a better use of Australian taxpayers' money than what the opposition is proposing. You cannot argue the case. This is not the best use of the money. This is an election 
 bribe that the government put up at the last election. It sounded like smart politics—I think it will turn out to be sour politics—but it is very bad economics. They did not get one public health economist to come and defend the scheme. They have not found one bit of methodology or calculation to support it. It is an absolute rort. It should not happen. It is a complete waste of taxpayers' money. I am extremely disappointed that we did not knock it off at the second reading stage, but I hope the Senate will reconsider. This is a gross misuse of taxpayers' money and it should not go ahead.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I do not know whether Senator Evans has any children, but it was his side that, with both hands, grabbed the child-care payments that were made to every millionaire and every other family in Australia. That is what was voted in by the Labor Party, but that is not the issue we are discussing tonight.
Similarly, when Senator Evans wants to take a swipe at me because I pay $2,000 a year in health care premiums, he should do some homework about the surcharge issues. He should also look at the costs of people who do take their services in private health insurance. He might like to revisit the comment that I made in the summing up where I made the point that, without private hospitals, the public system would have to treat an extra 1,800,000 patients a year, perform twice as much surgery as now, provide 23,000 more beds and require $3.5 billion extra funding every year. There is a certain degree of hypocrisy in what Senator Evans is getting at.
However, I would like to return to the issue that is germane to tonight, that is, we are discussing legislation with regard to the private health insurance rebate. Specifically, we are discussing Senator Lees's amendments. People should not start making second reading speeches because the broadcasting button has been turned on but should deal with the issues before us which are the amendments—and on this occasion they are the amendments moved by Senator Lees.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—Senator Tambling, I do not think this has anything to do with the broadcasting button but a lot to do with this government's inability to argue their case. As for your previous comments, private hospitals are not about to close down. I suggest you go and check the Stock Exchange. You will find that private hospitals are making record profits. If you do consult with those who advise on how to invest money, that is one of the top investments in this country at the moment. Indeed, shares have had a steady increase over about the last five years. Looking at new beds, in my home state in particular a new private hospital attached to Flinders is about to open. Looking at the number of new private hospitals established over the last 18 months, I think we have a surplus of something like 17 new private facilities, both bed day facilities and hospitals. We are far from the end of the private hospital system.
Again I would just make the point: this is not the way to support them anyway. If we do want to acknowledge that people pay Medicare and wish to use a private hospital, there is a bed-day subsidy which is putting health money into health; it is not putting health money into an insurance product.
Drawing our attention back to the amendment—as you keep wanting of us so that we will not ask too many more embarrassing questions—the amendment actually says that, while we do not want a bar of the measures you are putting before us tonight connected with the rebate, at least we should be quarantining the rebate to those Australians on low and middle incomes so that high income earners do not get something that they do not need.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I just indicate that the opposition will not be supporting these amendments. As I have tried to put, we think there is a need for greater equity in the scheme. But the problem with the amendments of the Democrats is that they reduce the benefits below those currently provided in the PHIIS—
—No, they do not.
—On the basis of the evidence I have seen, Senator Lees, you lower the means test to below the means test levels provided in the current scheme. On our analysis, you will be taking away benefits that people enjoy under the current scheme. Obviously that has caused us a difficulty. On that basis, we will not be supporting the amendments.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—If I can draw senators' attention to the amendments, you will see that we have left in place—and I think we need to go over to some later amendments—the actual existing scheme for those from the current threshold to the new threshold.
Amendments not agreed to.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—I move Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill amendment (3):
(3)	 Page 43 (after line 23), after clause 19-40, insert:
19-41  Review of operation of Act
	 (1)	 The Minister must cause an independent review to be undertaken of:
		 (a)	 the operation of the private health insurance incentives scheme as provided for by this Act and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance) Act 1998 ; and
		 (b)	 the extent to which the scheme has met the following performance objectives:
			 (i)	 the provision of gap insurance by health insurance funds;
			 (ii)	 the development of simplified billing arrangements between patients, providers and health insurance funds;
			 (iii)	 the reduction in health insurance premiums;
			 (iv)	 the increase in membership of health insurance funds;
			 (v)	 such other performance objectives as the review considers appropriate; and
		 (c)	 the impact of the scheme on the public hospital system, as measured by:
			 (i)	 the impact on public hospital waiting lists;
			 (ii)	 the impact on public hospital waiting times;  

			 (iii)	 such other measures as the review considers appropriate.
	 (2)	 A person who undertakes such a review must give the Minister a written report of the review within 2 years after the date of the commencement of this Act.
	 (3)	 The Minister must cause a copy of the report of the review to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days after receiving the report.
	 (4)	 In this section:
	 independent review  means a review undertaken by persons who:
		 (a)	 in the Minister's opinion possess appropriate qualifications to undertake the review; and
		 (b)	 include one or more persons who are not employed by the Department of State administered by the Minister, by the HIC or by a related Commonwealth authority and have not, in the 5 years immediately before the commencement of this Act, provided services to the Department, the HIC or the authority under, or in connection with, a contract.
19-42  Cessation of operation of Act
	 This Act, unless sooner repealed, ceases to be in force at the expiration of 3 years after the date of commencement of this Act.
I will speak to this amendment very briefly. Hopefully, the government will be interested in at least this one. This amendment puts in place a review. We would envisage a review by independent experts, including consumers as well as health economists, and no doubt the department would be involved. This would be specifically to look at the government's claims that this will reduce pressure on the public system. Also, it would look at the ability of this measure to hold down the costs of private health insurance over the two years and to do something about the number of people in private insurance. In other words, we are looking basically at what the government is claiming will happen. Surely the absolute minimum requirement would be to have a review to see whether or not this is working at all.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I just ask of Senator Lees: I understood that you were proposing to split this amendment—and correct me if I am 
 wrong—into two sections. I think we had indicated privately that we were happy to support one but not two. This is amendment 3 which deals with the review of the operation of the act and the cessation of the operation of the act; am I correct on that? I understood that you were going to consider moving them separately. Perhaps I could indicate that we were prepared to vote for the first part and not the second part, and that was why we were suggesting that you might move them separately.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—My advice is that the cessation in the act actually relates to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1998 and—the Clerk may wish to help me here—looking through the amendments, that is the only one that actually relates to cessation of the operation of the act.
—There are two parts, as I understand it: review of the operation of the act; and cessation of the operation of the act.
—Yes, I acknowledge that. I will need therefore to simply move the section on page 43 dealing with 19 to 41, the review of the operation.
—We will put them separately, Senator Lees.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Just for clarification: could somebody—perhaps Senator Lees—just advise us which of those includes the sunset clause. I think that is what you have been trying to establish. Which of those we are about to vote on does include some element of sunset clause?
—We have not come to the sunset clause. It is in this amendment but it is the second part, and we are putting them separately. It is under the heading `Cessation of operation of the act'.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I indicate again on behalf of the opposition that, as Senator Lees is moving just sections 19 to 41, which deal purely with the review of the operation of the act, we think that is a very sensible measure. While we do not have much confidence about the 
 bill generally or how the numbers are likely to fall tonight, clearly that is a measure worth supporting, and we will be voting for it.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I think there is a need for a review of the legislation. My personal view is that this could better be undertaken by a Senate committee; it then could be done in a more rigorous fashion than an independent review, run by a reviewer appointed by the minister. Under those circumstances, I would foreshadow that there should be, in the Senate, such a decision about it at this particular stage. Whether tonight or next year when we come back or, indeed, after 30 June, Senator Lees presumably can nominate whom she likes in that respect.
But quite seriously, I think it would be better if we did it through our committee system and did a thorough job on it. I would certainly be supporting that in due course. I can understand the point that Senator Lees has put, and I acknowledge what she has said: there does have to be a review. But let us conduct the review and let us deal with it in a thorough manner, as of course our committees do in any event.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text: —I had envisaged that that was where we would go after 1 July next year. After listening to Senator Margetts's comments earlier—and I believe her amendment should have been supported—I must say that some of these other roads will be pursued later next year, and I put the government on notice there. We saw this as simply the first stage of a longer process that would review how successful this measure had been. I take Senator Harradine's point. As long as we have Senator Harradine interested and he will be with us after July next year, then we can all be involved in the process of fully reviewing exactly what is happening with this legislation.

name: Knowles, Sen Susan
text:
—I want to endorse the comments of Senator Harradine. I think the parliamentary committees would be an ideal forum for a full and proper review of this matter. They have undertaken this requirement in 
 parts previously, and a further extension of that would certainly be desirable.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—It is interesting that Senator Knowles should say that because, when she was on her own trying to defend this situation on Friday, she quite clearly indicated that she did not think an inquiry was necessary.
—That is quite incorrect and I ask you to apologise and withdraw that.
—I was at the inquiry on Friday.
—Yes, but you weren't listening. It is quite incorrect and, if you don't apologise and withdraw it, I will speak and put the record straight.
—Feel free. If we were going to have a review on health funding, we should have had it before this nonsense tonight of trying to piece together something workable.

name: Knowles, Sen Susan
text:
—I need to set the record straight. Senator Margetts has not been involved in the previous inquiries the committee has undertaken and which I have chaired. Also, there was the Productivity Commission inquiry. That is the statement I made at the committee the other day. There was no reference to there being no requirement for further inquiries. Unfortunately, Senator Margetts left the committee meeting early and did not bother to stay until anywhere near the end.
—The question is that the amendment in respect of clause 19-41 be agreed to.
Amendment not agreed to.
—The question now is that the amendment in respect of clause 19-42 be agreed to.
Amendment not agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Lees) proposed:
(5)	 Clause 20-5, page 44 (lines 13 and 14), omit ", *ancillary cover or *combined cover".

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I indicate on behalf of the opposition that we will be supporting this amendment. The government has not made out a case for subsidising ancillary cover. As we know, 60 per cent of ancillary cover is in dental care. I have made the point in debates previously on this issue that the government's priority in this area is ironic. We are going to fund up to $200 million worth of ancillary care, which largely consists of dental care, for those in society who can afford it, while we as a community cannot afford emergency dental treatment for pensioners and others on low incomes because we have seen fit to abolish the Commonwealth dental scheme and remove the $100 million that was provided for that purpose.
So we have a very stark contrast. We can find $200 million to subsidise dental care for people of all income levels with ancillary cover, but we cannot find $100 million to provide emergency dental care for those people who sometimes cannot even eat because their teeth are in such bad condition but they cannot get care. It is an important representation of the government's priorities in this bill. It is an important representation of the choices confronting the Senate. I do not want to labour the point, but I do not think the government has made a case at all for us underwriting the provision of ancillary care.
Clearly, the government's major argument in all of this—however unconvincing—is that it will take the pressure off the public hospitals. This would do nothing to take the pressure off the public hospitals. These services are not generally provided in public hospitals. In terms of priorities for the use of money, the opposition cannot see any need to support the government's position. We therefore support the Democrat amendment.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—I would like to make a few comments. The government's argument in committee on this was that ancillary services are very important. We have no problem with that whatsoever; they are very important. They are sometimes a part of a hospital procedure but, as Senator 
 Evans has already said, the majority of them are dental and a lot of them are optical.
I have great difficulty with this when there has not been a drop-off in ancillary services. The pattern of private health insurance from 1995 shows that the number of people with hospital insurance dropped from 6.3 million to 5.7 million, but ancillary services remained stable. Roughly six million Australians are covered for those. As Senator Evans has pointed out, I have great difficulty subsidising mostly high income families and individuals, and remember there are already support mechanisms with the old system for those on low to middle incomes.
If this bill is passed tonight, what will really happen is this: of the $290 million that will go into subsidising ancillary services, a good $200 million will probably be spent on those on middle to high incomes, when we cannot find the money for dental treatment for those who are on waiting lists. They were once on waiting lists in the Commonwealth public dental scheme, but that has now been handed back to the states. In some states, such as Tasmania, that scheme is almost inoperable; that is true also for many rural areas across the country. In New South Wales, waiting lists for the public dental scheme are around three years and anyone could imagine what it would be like for someone to have to wait three years to have basic fillings attended to. In many instances, it is a case of having to extract their teeth by the time they reach the front of the queue.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—The critics of the rebate are arguing that the rebate should not apply to ancillary cover. To claim that only wealthy people use ancillary services is nonsense. Ancillary products cover such things as dental, optical, physiotherapy, chiropractic, osteopathy, podiatry, emergency ambulance transport, speech therapy, hearing aids and non-PSB pharmaceutical prescriptions. These services are used by all Australians, not just the wealthy. Indeed, 76 per cent of all people with health insurance have both hospital and ancillary cover, which shows that Australians across all income levels value 
 ancillary cover. It is not just the high-flying football players. It covers all people, especially those who are terminally ill with cancer, children with disability illnesses, the aged and the infirm, paraplegics and quadriplegics.
The majority of ancillary services are not covered by Medicare. Excluding ancillary services from the rebate would deny many less wealthy Australians access to these essential services. These are the very services that can prevent people from needing to go into hospital for acute care. For example, being able to access podiatry services can prevent a person with diabetes from being admitted to a hospital for a limb amputation. For those reasons we are certainly opposed to this amendment.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —The parliamentary secretary suggested that 76 per cent of those people holding health insurance have some form of ancillary cover. Perhaps he can tell us how that 76 per cent pans out in terms of income levels.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I do not have that information readily available. I will seek to get it for you.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—This is another example of where a figure is thrown into the debate and, if there are specific questions on that figure in this debate to the parliamentary secretary representing the minister, then there should be some means of backing up those figures. It might be just a debating point or it might have been something that was planned to put into the debate, but it is obvious that if the parliamentary secretary puts figures into the debate somebody is going to ask him about what makes up those figures.
—The question is that the amendment be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, against say no. I think the noes have it.
—Sorry. I am unaware of how Senators Colston and Harradine are voting on this one. Therefore, I am going to 
 need to put it to a division unless I am able to get some indication of that, because in the chamber I think we are dead even at the moment. No indication? Therefore, I say that the ayes have it.
—The ayes have it? Division required. Ring the bells.
	 Question put:
	 That the amendment (Senator Lees's ) be agreed to.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—by leave—I move amendments (1) to (6):
(1)	 Clause 14-15, page 30 (line 5), omit "subsection (2)", substitute "subsections (2) and (3)".
(2)	 Clause 14-15, page 30 (after line 11), at the end of the clause, add:
	 (3)	 The Minister must not approve an application by a *health fund for the financial year beginning on 1 July 2000 or a later financial year unless the health fund provides its members with the choice of one or more of the following types of policies:
		 (a)	 a *no gap policy;
		 (b)	 a *known gap policy.
(3)	 Clause 20-5, page 45 (after line 22), after the definition of  hospital cover , insert:
 hospital treatment  has the meaning given by section 3 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 .
(4)	 Clause 20-5, page 45 (after line 25), after the definition of  incentive payments scheme , insert:
 known gap policy  means a private health insurance policy that covers all but a specified amount or percentage of the full cost of hospital treatment and associated professional attention for the person or persons insured.
(5)	 Clause 20-5, page 45 (after line 28), after the definition of  Managing Director , insert:
 no gap policy  means a private health insurance policy that covers the full cost of hospital treatment and associated professional attention for the person or persons insured.
(6)	 Clause 20-5, page 47 (after line 4), after the definition of  private health insurance policy , insert:
 professional attention  has the meaning given by section 3 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 .
The legislation before the parliament provides for certain access options to the 30 per cent 
 rebate from 1 January 1999. It provides for access reductions of private health insurance premiums—namely, 30 per cent received by either of three areas: a reduction of private health insurance premiums, a tax rebate or a cash rebate from a government office, presumably the Medicare office. That is precisely what it is in the legislation at the moment.
The rebate could be used to put pressure on funds in negotiation with the medical profession to offer no gap or known gap policies to health fund members. National Mutual already offers such policies to its members in South Australia and in Victoria, and some 30 to 40 per cent of insured South Australian residents have such policies. Under simplified billing arrangements, there are now over 25 simplified billing agents across the country, and many of these also offer known or no gap arrangements for privately insured patients using both public and private hospitals.
These policies require negotiation between funds, hospitals and procedural specialists. Now over 5.7 per cent of all claims are going through simplified billing agencies. National Mutual has processed over 200,000 claims on its own. This amendment attempts to build on this achievement, and that is exactly what this incentive scheme should be doing. I have argued all along that the 30 per cent rebate should deal with the gaps issue. This has been a critical question in my mind in coming to the conclusion that I have come to within the last few hours: that is, to support this measure.
There were other factors which influenced my considerations thereon, but the issue of the gap is one which we have to deal with sooner or later, and the sooner the better. What these amendments do is deal with funds that do not offer these options to their members. These funds would no longer be permitted to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction. In other words, any fund that does not offer to its members a no gap or known gap policy would not be able to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction.
Therefore, the members could only access the rebate as a tax or cash rebate. Many who would be aware of this would move to other 
 funds that did meet the target and therefore could offer the 30 per cent premium reduction. The government cannot provide the committee with modelling to see how this would finally pan out, but anybody with any commonsense would realise that, in a competitive field such as private health insurance, the funds that could offer the no gap or known gap policies and therefore the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction would be at a considerable advantage in the marketplace as against those funds which would be unable to do that.
Those funds which would not offer that sort of policy would not be able to advertise or offer a cheaper premium based on the 30 per cent reduction in premium costs. Of course, the membership would be attracted to those that could. Clearly, it would provide an incentive to insurance companies to enter into agreements with private hospitals and with doctors, particularly specialists, so that they could offer the no gap or known gap policies. This is an advantage which should be considered by the committee as a step in the right direction to try to grapple with this vexed question of the gap.
I remind the committee that the thing that concerns members most is the cost of premiums, but this question of the gap is a matter that comes forward time and time again. People are complaining to us as members of parliament about it. You hear around the place in general conversation, `Yes, I had to go to the hospital. I was on top cover and thought I would be covered and now I'm receiving bill after bill after bill,' and those bills represent the amounts which were not picked up by Medicare or the fund and the person has to pay up out of their own pocket.
This is an attempt to overcome that situation. I appreciate that the funds would need a little time to ensure that this is worked out and to undertake the necessary negotiations with the private hospitals and with the medical profession. If the medical profession does not accept and cooperate and if they then do not themselves bring down their fees, then they are likely to face a real problem. If they do not do that, the whole private health system will be under so much pressure that it 
 is likely to collapse. I therefore submit these amendments to the committee in the hope that, though they are not the optimum, they are at least achievable with goodwill on all sides.
—That's what's needed.
—Yes, I agree, Senator Lees. I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the work you have done in the committee work and other areas. But at least these amendments are trying to address the problem. It might be argued that the doctors will just grasp this and say, `Oh, well, the funds will be responsible to pick up our tab, so we don't mind if we raise the fees. At least we won't have to send the bills to the patients. The health funds will have to pick up the tab.'
Those that do that I think would be seen as traitors to the private health system by their colleagues. There will be, I believe, a considerable incentive on the part of funds to ensure that costs are kept down, because if they are not then the members have to pay increased premiums. If the members have to pay increased premiums, that is the primary concern of members. That will lead to the destruction of the private health insurance funds and, ultimately, to the private system itself. Those doctors surely would be regarded as traitors to that particular cause.
I submit this as workable and also constitutional. There are other ways to try to pull the doctors, the medical profession, into line. That has been tried in a number of fields. Much of the work therein was useless because it was considered to be unconstitutional. This is not an unconstitutional provision. I urge the Committee to at least accept this as a start.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—Firstly, I say to Senator Harradine that I am pleased to see we have a step in the right direction. Just on that basis we would support it. However, unfortunately I see within this many problems—first of all, the way in which this amendment is worded. It says:
. . . unless the health fund provides its members with the choice of one or more of the following types of policies: 

I think virtually every health insurance company already fulfils this, and I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary if that is not indeed true.
My preferred option would have been that the 30 per cent rebate could only be available on policies where there was going to be no gap—in other words, if we could really have driven down the cost of those policies that really did offer everything. Looking at my home state, I congratulate the largest fund there. It has managed to do that, and a lot of people are now using that option. But my worry is that, given that in each state, except one state, there is a dominant insurer, the no-gap policy could indeed end up costing $6,000 and the premiums for ordinary existing policies for everyday hospital cover, which the minister has the final say in, would manage to stay down because the gaps will still be there. Those full hospital policies are the ones where you often get surgical and other gaps added on at the end, whereas with some policies there are absolutely no gaps.
I ask the parliamentary secretary: is it not the case already that most funds do provide the no-gap policy? In relation to the known gap, I ask the parliamentary secretary a second question: is it not the case already, and it is has been proven at law, that if a person wants to pursue a bill that they had no prior knowledge of they do not have to pay it anyway?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I would like to respond to the comments of both Senator Harradine and Senator Lees. The government supports Senator Harradine's important amendment, as it goes a long way to supporting initiatives the government is already pursuing to address the issues of the gap. In fact, the Howard government has done more to reduce the incidence of the medical gap fees than the previous government. In the last 18 months we have seen major successes which would have been unimaginable only three years ago. HIC statistics show that an increasing number of in-hospital medical claims are being processed through agreements with health funds and through simpli 
 fied billing agents, many of which have eliminated gaps or shown known out-of-pockets.
I draw attention to this whole issue of the success that we have had in Victoria and South Australia with a number of admissions to hospitals with a no-gaps basis rising exponentially. We have a real prospect of making major changes nationally within the next 18 months. Certainly, in the calendar year 1998, we have gone from no no-gaps product existing in the country to no-gaps products being common place in two states and in early stages of start-up in others.
I know that Dr Wooldridge has talked at length about how we can hasten this. He, of course, has referred to the areas where we will be providing money for computer software development, which is one of the limiting factors, to changing the reinsurance pool to provide greater incentives for funds to offer no-gap products. Within the last week, Dr Wooldridge has brought Medibank Private to his office and instructed work in this area as a matter of urgency.
You will recall that the  Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1998  has just passed through the House of Representatives, and it has a number of measures to help costs, such as attempting to create a wholesale market in private health insurance and removing incentives for in-hospital treatment when a procedure could be done in rooms or as day surgery. Certainly much more needs to be done. Senator Harradine's amendment will help immeasurably in this regard, and we acknowledge its important contribution to this part of the legislation.
Senator Lees asked about the issue of existing policies. I am informed that current covers are only in the area that relates to hospital costs and cover such issues as accommodation, whereas the extension of what is now envisaged in Senator Harradine's amendment picks up new and innovative products that will be available and will move into the wider areas of medical assessment and medical need. We are certainly pleased to support Senator Harradine's amendment.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I will start by congratulating 
 Senator Harradine. I thought his second reading contribution was cogent, reasoned and convincing. I am sure anyone listening would have been convinced—if they had not been convinced when they heard the debate earlier—to vote down the bill. Unfortunately, he then reached a different conclusion to the one the whole logic and force of his argument had taken him to. I do not quite understand why, but I accept that he did.
What we have here is, it seems, a result of some discussions between the government and Senator Harradine this afternoon. The parliamentary secretary has indicated that the government is responding to what I think he described as `Senator Harradine's initiatives'. I suppose that goes to confirm the letter that I was given recently which purports to be from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine confirming arrangements that they have reached between them regarding health insurance. I want to ask a couple of questions about those matters shortly.
This amendment is a very meagre step in the right direction. And, given all the criticisms that Senator Harradine and others made which highlighted that the bill did not tackle the real issues of private health insurance, this amendment did not tackle the funding of health care in this country. This amendment is a very unsatisfactory sole sign of moving to deal with one of those problems. What we are doing here is providing a $1.7 billion blank cheque and saying, `In addition to that, we might have this small amendment moved, and carried by the government, that would provide some signal that there would be some serious attempt to deal with the problem of the gap.'
I agree with Senator Harradine that the gap is one of the major issues. I think all minor party and Labor senators have stressed that this does nothing for that major issue, that we are throwing good money after bad without any of the reciprocal obligation that the government demands of social security recipients or unemployed persons in this country. In return for $300 a week of pension, all sorts of reciprocal and mutual obligations are demanded. But in return for $1.7 billion we demand nothing. We say, `Take the money 
 and we will have a look at some of the other problems down the track.'
Quite frankly, if Dr Wooldridge was in business, he would go broke very quickly. You never give them the money before you get the service. You certainly do not give them the money before you get some sort of sign of their commitment to provide some service in return. What we have done is provided an underwriting of 30 per cent of whatever the private health insurance funds choose to charge over the next however many years. They can increase premiums, knowing that we will always pay 30 per cent of the bill. I think that is an outrage in terms of public policy. While this amendment has some worthy objectives, it takes us no real way towards meeting our obligation to deal with the real problems or ensuring that we get a proper response from the health insurance industry.
Senator Harradine referred to the problem of modelling and costing that we found with the government's proposals, and I think he indicated that he had similar difficulties in costing this proposal. I think it is important that he or the parliamentary secretary provide some explanation, because the evidence given to the Senate committee of inquiry into this matter indicated that the cost of providing gap insurance would actually increase premiums by some 7½ per cent. I am not sure what the government and Senator Harradine are saying about this measure but, on the evidence of the private hospital industry, gap insurance would increase the total cost of premiums by 7½ per cent. Is that right? Is that the estimate of the cost of this measure—an increase in premiums of 7½ per cent? Is that the government's estimate as well?
And, will we be subsidising 30 per cent of that increase in cost? Is there any limit on the charges that can be applied to gap insurance? Surely it is going to be quite an expensive product, by anybody's reckoning. I would be interested to know what sort of restrictions or flexibility apply in that regard. Will any measures be taken to cap the cost of gap fees? I understood that Mr Chalmers of the private industry stated in his evidence at the committee hearing that there are no mechanisms by 
 which gaps can be quantified or capped. It is unclear to me how this measure is to work, how it is to be funded, or what the government estimates the cost of the measure to be. Obviously, some answers to those questions would assist the committee greatly.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—There are several issues that arise. I am surprised at Senator Evans's cynicism with regard to the bona fides of this particular amendment and the advantages that it certainly will bring. Whilst everyone has acknowledged the role that Senator Harradine has been able to play in brokering this important issue, I am sure there are many other parties whose willingness to reach real solutions should be acknowledged, such as the Australian Private Hospitals Association, the AMA and, in particular, the chairman, Dr Brand—I hope that he will not be undermined by people within his own area that have perhaps a different view to the executive of the AMA; we have certainly been cooperative and willing to pursue this matter very carefully and very properly—and, of course, the Private Health Insurance Association, which naturally has vested interests.
I think the leadership and the cooperation of those people need to be particularly commended.
