I believe that the challenge of this particular amendment will impose disciplines and special requirements on each of those areas. The doctors themselves, we acknowledge, will have an important role to play in the partnership, as will the hospitals and the various insurance companies.
Senator Evans asked a question with regard to intended premium rises. I am informed that it has been generally indicated that increases in premiums would certainly be much lower than any figures you have used—the seven per cent or so.
—No, as a result of this measure.
—I am sure as a result of this measure that increases would be lower—and also that they would not necessarily be implemented in the normal program of dates, which I think was intended to be about 
 March. It will probably be later. Any deferment in that area will, of course, have advantages as well.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text: —I want to ask Senator Harradine about the modelling that no doubt understraps these amendments and the health minister's statement that the government's rebate proposal would increase participation in health funds by three per cent and also prevent a projected fall in participation from 30 to 20 per cent over the coming five to 10 years. How will this measure enhance those figures? If it does not, it will be a failed measure. In other words, is it going to increase the participation rate in the health funds by more than three per cent?

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —If I could add to that question, I wonder if Senator Harradine might advise whether he believes a decline in private health insurance is per se a problem or the problem, and whether or not the survival of the private system depends on private health insurance. We have had issues about figures and the inability, as we have all seen, of the government to be able to justify the modelling. We have had dubious claims about the rebate taking pressure off the public health system for all the reasons given to us, including the fact that it is inevitable that money gets taken out of the bottom if there is money going out the top, equity measures, opportunity costs and so on. I wonder if that basic question might be addressed by Senator Harradine: is it his belief that the decline in health insurance is a problem or the problem?

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—If I could respond to the matters that have been raised with me in the order in which they have been raised. Senator Chris Evans indicated that he has a letter to me from the Prime Minister. He has been pretty sharp. I received that letter at 8.10 p.m. on 10 December, which is today. I understand the Prime Minister's office has released that letter, and I gave the okay for that. I think it would be desirable, since the letter is now in the public domain, to have the letter incorporated into Hansard . I seek leave to incorporate it into Hansard .
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
Senator Brian Harradine
Senator for Tasmania
Suite S1.38
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Harradine
I refer to our recent discussions on the Government's private health insurance rebate legislation.
I consider that you have raised quite legitimate concerns about the `gaps' paid by people receiving treatment as privately insured patients. The Government believes that the amendment you have circulated would substantially address this problem and, accordingly, will support it. I note that the amendment would have the effect of setting a target of all private health insurance products having no gaps or known gaps by 1 July 2000. Funds that did not meet the target would not be permitted to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction after that date. All fund contributors would, of course, retain access to a taxation or direct cash rebate.
I can also confirm that the Government will promote the facilitating measures concerning out of pocket costs and medical gaps previously discussed with Dr Wooldridge. These include:
.	 providing money for computer software development which is one of the limiting factors;
.	 changing the reinsurance pool to provide greater incentives for funds to offer no gap products; and
.	 asking Medibank Private to work on this area, as a matter of urgency.
We also discussed the provision of measures to alleviate the health problems of the aged and chronically ill. As you know, I made a major commitment at the recent ACOSS Congress to advance substantially the quality of health care delivered to older people, in the context of the International Year of Older Persons. Specifically, we will be:
.	 providing through Medicare for general practitioners to be involved in multi disciplinary care planning in case management for those with chronic and complex needs;
.	 giving incentives at the practice level for Gps to achieve multi disciplinary care plans for those over 65, or with chronic or complex need; and
.	 for those over 75, pay doctors to undertake an annual health assessment to focus on issues of prevention and better management of chronic illness. 
Further, we talked of the provision of a coordinated care plan for disadvantaged elderly people. This would be a very substantial change in our health care system and the Government is prepared to trial 
 it seriously. It is dependent on being able to cash-out hospital costs for a given group of people or a defined geographic area. The Government would also be willing to cash-out Medicare or pharmaceutical costs. I can confirm that in the next Budget, the Government will provide funds in the order of $25 million to run additional coordinated care trials in capital cities and selected regional centres to address the health care needs of older people who are chronically ill or disadvantaged.
The Government would, of course, appreciate your support in securing passage of the legislation in its amended form.
Yours sincerely
John Howard
—Senator Evans raised questions about possible increases in premiums that the covering of the gap would entail. I suggest to Senator Evans that that has not been the experience of the National Mutual company in South Australia, as I understand the situation. These figures are available. I do not have them with me. As I understand it, you have got National Mutual already offering those policies to its members in South Australia.
—Why do we need these amendments then?
—To encourage that sort of activity elsewhere. Perhaps I can deal with Senator Margetts's question in regard to this matter at the same time. The whole point about it is that the medical profession does acknowledge the fact that, if there is a breakdown in the health insurance system, the public hospital system will also go down the drain. We do have to look at the effects not only on those hospitals and on the membership of the funds—and let us understand that 30 per cent of people are now in funds—but also on the public hospital system itself if the other system breaks down. That is something that has been concerning me for some considerable time.
In response to Senator Margetts's question, the decline of the health insurance industry is not per se a problem, if you talk about per se, but the effects of that on both the members of the organisations and the public hospital system would, I believe, be quite disconcerting, if not devastating. Senator Brown, I am not sure I understood your question correctly. Maybe you could clarify it for me.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text: —The question comes out of the figures that the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, gave to me where he predicted that his measures in this legislation would increase the participation rate in insurance by three per cent. We would go from 30 per cent to 33 per cent. I know you were keen to have modelling on what the legislation was going to do. I wonder whether you have had modelling or whether you have had it from the government as to what improvement in that participation rate above 33 per cent your amendment will mean.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—No, I have not. Obviously the legislation does not consist of my measures. In fact, Senator Evans was correct when he referred to my speech. I indicate to the chamber that I prepared that speech—
—A couple of days ago.
—Well, I have been pretty flat out today. It has been a bit of a problem to change it.
—The last paragraph was different.
—Honourable senators might like to have a look in due course at the letter that I have incorporated in Hansard . It might indicate something as well.
In answer to Senator Brown, no, I have not. Surely it stands to reason that, if funds can make arrangements with the private hospitals and with the medical specialists, particularly in certain areas, then clearly it is going to mean that the funds will be more and more attractive—those funds that at least have that no gap or known gap policy. They will be more attractive because they will be able to offer the cheaper premium rates—the rates which are discounted by 30 per cent—whereas those that do not have those policies will not be able to offer the rates. You might see some adjustment amongst those particular funds. There would then be even more incentive for them and others to undertake the necessary discussions and negotiations with the medical profession and with the private hospitals.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—The difficulty with Senator Harradine's response is that it does come down to a supposition that there is going to be improved participation in health insurance because of the amendment he has made. The opposition has already made the point that one outcome is likely to be higher premiums, which has exactly the opposite effect because it would see more people shedding their private insurance. We are in the situation here of not knowing and that means, to some degree, flying by the seat of our pants.
It is a very important matter, because the alternative that the opposition and the Greens have been putting quite strongly is that it would be better for the $1.7 billion to be going into the public health system. This would have a very clear impact for the good on the medical health services delivery to the Australian populace as a whole.
The problem with Senator Harradine's amendment is that while it appears on the face of it that there may be some beneficial effect in increasing the participation in health insurance, beyond that we have nothing to go by. We are being asked to give up the alternative of a much improved public health system—if the money went in that direction—in the hope that there will be some degree of improvement in participation rates in private health insurance.
We have already heard Senator Harradine say that it would be traitorous for doctors to increase fees on the back of this measure. But there is nothing in this amendment or in the legislation to stop that happening. Doctors—and I am one of them—are human beings and past practice has shown that some of them at least will move to take monetary advantage from a system that allows them to do so. The only way we can stop that is by regulating. I would be much happier as a member of the medical profession if that were an outcome that we were entertaining here tonight. But we are not. Therefore, what the argument for this measure comes down to is that it sounds like a good idea.
One thing I would like to know, which might help the committee in deciding whether this idea is going to be effectual, is what the 
 participation rate in South Australia has been compared with other states. Has the participation rate in South Australia improved in recent times because of the availability of the no gap or known gap alternatives or hasn't it? If we could have those figures, it would give us some indication—even though it would be broad brush—as to whether in effect offering that policy option generally to the Australian populace is going to make a difference.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—At the risk of being accused of cynicism, I share Senator Brown's doubts about some of the claims being made for the proposition. Not much can be expected of propositions drawn up in haste without public scrutiny. This suffers from some of those faults. Senator Harradine has already admitted that this can be done and is already occurring, so I am not quite sure what the great impact of this alleged legislative support will be. I will return to it in a minute. There is no implementation for 18 months, so this is not a measure that will have any immediate impact. It suffers from a lack of review and defined objectives. But, as I say, there are some worthy sentiments contained in it.
I raised some concerns earlier. I think the parliamentary secretary may have misunderstood. I was not asking him what the costs of the measure are in terms of the package of the government's legislation; I was asking him what the costs will be of the amendment from Senator Harradine that has been agreed to by the government. Senator Lees asked the very question that Senator Harradine seeks to answer by this measure tonight. Mr Chalmers, from the Private Hospitals Association, provided the answer. This is not one of those witnesses who so upset Senator Knowles; this was Mr Chalmers from the Private Hospitals Association. When asked by Senator Lees about gap payments, he said at page 42 of the Hansard:
Senator, while my colleague is thinking about that, we have just done some quick `back of the notepad' calculations at the table. To answer the question of what would be the premium effect of covering existing medical gaps, that would require a premium increase in the order of 7.5 per cent. However, that would not necessarily ensure that the gap problem would be eliminated because there is 
 no mechanism by which gaps can be quantified or capped.
So Mr Chalmers from the Private Hospitals Association seemed to be indicating that the idea was a nonsense and that it was not feasible.
The parliamentary secretary may or may not agree with that. Given that he is voting for the amendment and co-sponsoring it, I assume he does not accept that view. But does he accept, and has the government done the calculations on, the cost to premiums of the gap insurance? Do you agree with the private hospitals' estimate that it will cost a 7.5 per cent increase in premiums? Senator Harradine has now put this letter into the Hansard. I appreciate his doing that. I was not sure how I would come by it. I wanted to be a bit careful. I was not even sure that it was genuine, even though it was handed to me by Senator O'Brien, who is usually a most reliable source. It just got handed to me a few minutes ago. I am glad that Senator Harradine has corrected the public record.
In this letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine, the government seems to have agreed to a whole range of measures in addition to the one provided for in the amendment. They go to a number of trials, incentives, a reinsurance pool and computer software development. They include $25 million to run additional coordinated care trials in capital cities and selected regional centres. In addition to the question I asked about the cost of the premium increase, I ask: what is the total cost of the contents of the letter to Senator Harradine? What is the financial impact of these commitments on the Commonwealth government?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—I am pleased to note that Senator Evans once again notes how his introductory comments are often couched with cynicism. However, I do take seriously the questions that he has raised. One of the very important issues that must be addressed when we are dealing with private health insurance is the retention rate within the funds themselves. For many years now, the fall-off in membership has been one of the 
 most serious factors influencing the continuation of premiums and, in fact, rising premiums for members who stay within the funds.
Senator Brown referred to the South Australian experience. I know that National Mutual in South Australia has acknowledged that, in the changes to the system this year, the retention of membership has been one of the key goals. It is a very major economic factor in keeping the premiums either stable or as tightly measured as possible.
Senator Harradine's amendments now reinforce that opportunity for the funds to have innovative, new and special products that will not only appeal to retaining membership but also, hopefully, to expanding it and encouraging people in different areas. It will certainly be very focused in that area. The costs will have to be measured by the funds. Naturally, there will be normal economic adjustments based on their membership and participation, which are so vitally important. I believe that this amendment will go a long way to stabilising that area.
Senator Evans referred to the letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine of today's date which acknowledges and puts on the record a number of the government's very important initiatives, not only those that Dr Wooldridge has been keenly pursuing now for some time in a number of particular areas and which I mentioned earlier in the debate this evening. The fact that Dr Wooldridge has been working for some time now in the area of gaps naturally meant that he, Senator Harradine and the Prime Minister were able to reach some very important agreements on this whole matter of the objectives that have surfaced in Senator Harradine's amendments.
Senator Evans refers to the other parts of the letter in which the Prime Minister acknowledges, very properly, to Senator Harradine that there are a number of other ongoing government programs to which he has alluded previously, particularly at the recent ACOSS Congress. Certainly, I am aware of the directives and the determination of both the Prime Minister and Dr Wooldridge in changing the areas of quality health care and how that is to be achieved, 
 particularly measuring outcomes in a number of ways. The Prime Minister has quite rightly set out that there will be initiatives in the context of the International Year of Older Persons and has named a number of specific projects that the government was in the course of developing and has put on the record.
With regard to the area that Senator Evans mentioned, the coordinated care trials, I am pleased to note that the Prime Minister has confirmed a particular amount—and it may even be larger when the budget comes around—for these important projects. The coordinated care trials will have tremendous advantage not only for aged and elderly people but also for people in regional centres throughout Australia. I can speak from personal experience, as there are currently two such coordinated care trials operating in the Northern Territory, specifically in Aboriginal communities. They will have a major impact in delivering important health care outcomes.
I for one would certainly acknowledge that it is important that coordinated care trials should be expanded and built up to address the area of care for people in regional centres. If they are as successful as those that are operating in the Territory and elsewhere in Australia, I am sure that the advantage to people—particularly older people—who are chronically ill or disadvantaged will have a major impact.
I am sure that Senator Harradine welcomed the letter. I would say that most people in the community certainly would have. Many more of the items will be advanced in budget considerations and will certainly appear in full detail in the forward estimates in the budget.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—I will ask the parliamentary secretary two questions but before I do that I will comment on something Senator Harradine said about his concerns at the way the level of private health insurance is dropping. Senator Harradine, even if we went down to only 20 per cent insured, that would cost us only $830 million to $900 million per year and not the $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion in this spending.
Parliamentary Secretary, I asked you earlier if it was not the case already that if people 
 wished to pursue unknown gaps—in other words, if they went in for an operation believing they were fully covered but then got a gap payment—they could take that through the process and find out that they did not have to pay. Hasn't that already been tried at law? Secondly, the minister has to approve increases in the cost of premiums set for the funds. Will the minister agree to an increase of what I suspect Mr Chalmers is right in saying is going to be about 7½ per cent on top of the increase that is already in the pipeline for next year—an increase that we understand is somewhere between five per cent and eight per cent?

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Whilst the parliamentary secretary is seeking advice on that matter, perhaps I could add a further question. Part of the premise upon which the amendments are based is, I believe, that there will be a choice and an option, once there are further incentives, for health schemes to offer `no gap' or `no known gap' insurance. It sounds a bit like a product for sticking windows together, doesn't it? Once there is that extra incentive, what does it mean for states if they have very few choices already in health insurance packages or products? Does the parliamentary secretary have any specific figures on the coverage of health insurance and the numbers of health insurance products that are available in each state? I believe that in Western Australia we may have three. If that is not true, perhaps you can clarify that. What would happen? Is the government able to take any action if all three funds get together and decide not to offer this package?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—First I will address the two issues raised by Senator Lees. Her first question was in regard to unknown gaps. I am advised that that particular area would be treated as for any other debts. The second question posed was whether the government would agree to any increases on top of what may already be contemplated. Again, I am advised that we do not anticipate that any increases would be in the same proportion as those of previous years. In 
 fact, Senator Harradine's amendment opens the area for negotiation to militate against this.
Senator Margetts raised the question of how the impact would influence states and the agreements. Certainly, the recently negotiated arrangements with the states have been important. With regard to the public health systems area, I would remind Senator Margetts that the Howard government has provided the biggest ever increase in funding for public health systems: over $7.2 billion, an increase of 19 per cent. In forecasting that into the future, we have to be very mindful of the impact on national budgets. Any improvement in the area of private health insurance will militate against those future imposts on states.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for his answer, but that was not actually the question I asked. I may have said `packages' when I meant `funds'. Does the parliamentary secretary have some information he can provide to us about the number of funds that exist in states or territories? What would happen if, in a state or territory which had only a few funds, none of those funds offered a package for no gaps?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —We will certainly make that information available to Senator Margetts. With regard to the arrangements in states, I am firmly of the view that the innovation proposed in these amendments is going to create a special market pressure on funds, no matter where they are located—in any state or territory—and I am sure that it will be a very competitive market.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I will just follow that up because Senator Margetts raised one of the scenarios. I want to take us back to one of the clauses in the amendments that Senator Harradine has moved. The proposed clause states:
The Minister must not approve an application by a *health fund for the financial year beginning on 1 July 2000 or a later financial year unless the 
 health fund provides its members with the choice of one or more of the following types of policies:
(a)	 a *no gap policy;
(b)	 a *known gap policy.
In effect, that looks like a sanction that is to be applied against the health funds—that is, unless they provided this choice, there would be some sanction. The letter that Senator Harradine received today from the Prime Minister, which has been incorporated, states:
I note that the amendment would have the effect of setting a target of all private health insurance products having no gaps or known gaps by 1 July 2000. Funds that did not meet the target would not be permitted to offer the 30 per cent rebate as a premium reduction after that date. All fund contributors would, of course, retain access to a taxation or direct cash rebate.
It seems to be a slightly different understanding of the sanction. So I would like some clarification as to whether the sanction is to be applied against the health funds if they do not provide this choice or, as it appears in the Prime Minister's letter, whether the only sanction is that they would not be able to offer that particular rebate as a premium reduction, that people would still be able to get the taxation or direct cash rebate.
Is the sanction on the fund really only restricting them in terms of one of the three options of paying the rebate to people but not restricting them from continuing not to offer the policies that you are suggesting are vital? I just want to get it clear what Senator Harradine thinks the amendment does.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—That is precisely what the amendment does. That is a penalty. Is that not a sufficient penalty? You could then have a number of funds offering the no gap or known gap policies having their premiums presented to potential fund members at a particular rate; others would not. Those that did not so offer could not provide on any of their tables a cut rate from their premium.
In the marketplace—if you are talking about the marketplace—it is an enormous advantage and an enormous incentive for funds to make sure that they offer this particular product, and it is what I propose in this amendment. To do otherwise would be to penalise the 
 fund members for the failure of the fund to do what it ought to be doing. It would be unfair to penalise the fund members by taking away their 30 per cent reduction provided either by cash or through the taxation system. When advertising, the funds that were not participating and were not offering these particular policies would be at a great disadvantage because, in particular tables by comparison with the other funds, their premiums would have to be advertised 30 per cent above the others.
I come back to a point that you made. You are concerned about the failure of this to cap the fees that are charged by specialists. I think it will have the effect of capping them because there will be a lot of pressure on the funds to come to arrangements with public hospitals, particularly with medical specialists. But, let me make it clear to the committee, as most members of the committee must know, that it is, unfortunately, unconstitutional for the parliament to cap the fees of medical specialists. Senator Brown said we ought to be regulating them. Quite frankly, I tell you right here and now that I would be the first one doing that. But we cannot. I have been through it the last few weeks and you cannot do it. The states do have the powers to fix fees, but we do not. I know it is not perfect, but at least it is an advance. I am putting it to the committee and am hoping that it will be carried.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—We ought to have the states come together with the Commonwealth for that purpose. We do it on so many other things, so I cannot see why we cannot do it when coming to an arrangement on capping medical fees. That seems to me to be an extremely good goal.
I want to raise two things. What improvement has there been in the participation rate in South Australia, which has this system that is being advocated or promoted in this amendment, vis-a-vis the other states? Margaret in my office tells me that, in 1997, hospital cover in South Australia—this is an average sort of scheme—had gone to 267 per cent of 1989 levels compared with 220 per cent for the country as a whole. In other 
 words, premiums have gone up faster in South Australia than they have in the rest of the country. Is this related to the fact that South Australia had this rapid change across to a known gap option? I do not know, but that is the sort of thing this committee should know.
It is a pity that we do not have time here to look at the ramifications of this amendment. I suggest, Senator Harradine, that it would have been a more assured outcome for you had the analysis and scrutiny that should have taken place on this amendment been made before we had the vote on it. As it is, nothing is going to change.
The other point evident here is: sure, as Senator Harradine says, some funds will be able to say, `Look, our premiums are 30 per cent lower.' But what is to stop the other funds from saying, `Look, our premiums are higher, but you're going to get a cheque in the mail or a tax deduction as a result of this new scheme coming in, and overall our premiums will be lower.' If the only thing to come out of this is to be an advertising advantage that will induce people into the funds, all of us in this committee know that a good advertising person will be able to put the argument in the other direction if fund participants themselves are to be able to get the benefit of the rebate—even if the fund cannot give it in reduction of cost of premiums.
I think we will not see much good result at all come out of this amendment. But we will see a heck of a lot of money go from the government coffers, into the rebate incentive, into the private system. As a committee, we are left with no figures, no modelling, no argument essentially, other than this being a good advertising way of increasing membership. I just do not think that is good enough, particularly considering the amount of money that is involved.

name: Evans, Sen Chris
text:
—I agree with Senator Brown, but his arguments against Senator Harradine's amendment hold true of the whole bill. While I think it is a good argument, as I say, the government has not provided any modelling for any of this, so I do not think it takes us 
 much further. Yes, we have another amendment that is uncosted, unmodelled, with no real idea of impact—but then the whole bill is like that. So I have given up on that argument. That has had no weight and no success in moving the Senate more generally.
I do not want to spend too much time on this because, quite frankly, I think it is a very modest minor amendment that does not go to the heart of this bill nor to the heart of the problems of private health insurance. I think the sort of thing that Senator Harradine talked about in terms of sanction is more of a minor inconvenience to the funds. Nevertheless, that is not really essential debate on the bill. I do not think we ought to delay the committee stage too long on that issue. I think there are much bigger issues in terms of the bill.
I think it is unfortunate that we have not got any costings out of the parliamentary secretary in relation to this measure, nor in relation to the undertakings given to Senator Harradine. They obviously add to the total cost of this package; they add to the money that the government is throwing at getting this package through the parliament—and I think it is not unreasonable for us to expect to have that properly costed and be put before the parliament. But that is obviously not going to happen.
Again, I do not want to labour the point, but it is more money thrown at the problem in order to get the bill passed, because that is the political imperative. There is no health imperative, there is no economic imperative. It is just, `Throw money at the problem, get it fixed, get it passed; if we need to give $25 million for coordinated care, we'll throw that in as well; when you've got $1.5 billion, what's another $25 million? It's all big numbers and it's all got out of control, and there's no basis for any of it, there's no modelling for any of it—so, what the heck, what's a bit more? But the failure of the government to provide any costing on that I think is a sad reflection.
I just want to make this clear: the Labor Party is most concerned about gaps. They are a major issue. They need to be treated seriously. They need to be treated more seriously than was possible, it seems, in a couple of 
 hours of discussions this afternoon in order to get a compromise to get the bill passed. What we proposed—and what the Democrats and the Greens proposed—was a proper look at these issues; that we would not pass this bill until we dealt with the gaps issue, until we dealt with the premium rises issue and had a coordinated thorough look at how to get good health policy. What we have instead is a slipshod bill that is throwing money at the problem, throwing money at people who do not need support, and denying that health support to people who do need it.
As I say, I do not want to labour this issue any longer. I do not disagree with the objectives; I think they are worthy. It is a major issue that needs to be tackled. I do not think this amendment goes anywhere near far enough in dealing with that. But that is not to say that it is not worth supporting, in the sense that it is at least giving some recognition to the problem and some recognition to the fact that we need to do much more about gaps and premiums. But, as I say, we will not solve those problems tonight because there is no serious attempt to deal with those problems in this bill.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—Senator Brown raised the issue of the statistics based on South Australia. Obviously he has put them together based on anecdotal comment, whether in his office or elsewhere. But I appreciate his concern. I will seek that information for him. I was under the impression that what he was seeking was rather like comparing apples and pears, particularly with regard to the time scales covered. Looking at the prospective nature of what is intended in this legislation and the advantages of keeping people in a good and proper and balanced system, I thought they would be more the objectives and the purposes that we ought to be focusing on.
Both Senator Evans and Senator Brown have raised a number of commercial and economic issues in that area, whether relating to the sanctions or other issues. All I can say is that, from my experience in business, obviously there is a big difference between 
 us: with their appreciation of the factors of commerce and economic priorities and business operations, I would say that they are way off the track.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Just quickly, I would put one little perspective on this. If the competitive market is used as the model for the way this particular measure will work, you have to keep in mind that a competitive model works on full information. So I guess that people actually would have to go off and find out the information from the various health funds.
But also with the ability to quickly transfer, I believe—and, okay, these are my personal feelings—that people generally stick with a fund, unless they make a major decision to change. If I am not mistaken, that usually happens because there are substantial penalties with what you can claim and what you cannot claim. I do not know that you can transfer those over from one fund to another, but for many kinds of health care you have to wait a certain number of years.
The private health insurance market operates in such a way that people will not transfer from one fund to the other, like in superannuation, because they are concerned about losing benefits they have to wait several years to obtain. The reality is that this market does not operate in the way a lot of other markets operate—not even in the way superannuation funds operate—and we have to keep those issues in mind when we think about incentives we are offering to create a market situation or to keep people in a market. It might have an impact on attracting new people to the market, but this has been unproven in all the statistics we have been asked to believe. In reality, it will not necessarily operate as a real market incentive for those existing clients of health insurance, because you are unable to easily move from one fund to the other without losing some of the benefits you have to wait for.

name: West, Sen Sue
text:
—I am looking at the Prime Minister's letter and the third paragraph states:
I can also confirm that the Government will promote the facilitating measures concerning out of 
 pocket costs and medical gaps previously discussed with Dr Wooldridge. These include:
.	 providing money for computer software development which is one of the limiting factors;
What precisely is meant by `one of the limiting factors'? I do not understand what is meant by that. What are these limiting factors? Can somebody identify more clearly what is meant by that sentence?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I am advised that it is electronic transfer of information for billing purposes.

name: West, Sen Sue
text:
—I will pursue that one at estimates with a great deal of interest to look at the privacy aspects in a few of those. It is the third point that really interests me, which states that the government will be:
. . . 	 asking Medibank Private to work on this area, as a matter of urgency.
What compensation is going to be put in place for Medibank Private to undertake this work? What are the guidelines and the terms of reference for the work that Medibank Private will undertake?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —Given that Senator West is quoting from a letter of today's date, I think it is quite appropriate to point out that these are matters that will be developed between the various parties.

name: West, Sen Sue
text: —It is a bit like a pig in a poke. Medibank Private was separated from Medicare some time ago as far as its accommodation was concerned, because there was a need, we were told, for it to be able to compete and it had to be put on a level playing field. I want to ensure that Medibank Private remains on a level playing field. I would have thought this had already been considered and, according to this letter, this is not the first time this discussion has happened. What guarantees can the government give to ensure that Medibank Private remains on a level playing field?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —This is not a matter that really relates to this particular legislation. Whilst the Prime Minister's letter and my comments earlier this evening referred to the conversations between Dr Wooldridge and Medibank Private, they are matters that will be pursued and Medibank Private will be competing with other funds already offering no gaps. I am sure the matters of detail will be addressed between Dr Wooldridge and Medibank Private.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—I do not understand how the parliamentary secretary can make that point. We have in our possession a letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine, which has kindly been provided, that commences:
Dear Senator Harradine
I refer to our recent discussions on the Government's private health insurance rebate legislation.
And it concludes:
The Government would, of course, appreciate your support in securing passage of the legislation in its amended form.
The issues of substance that Senator West raised happen to be in the body of the letter. How can the parliamentary secretary seriously say to this committee that this matter is not relevant to the legislation that is being debated by the committee at this time? It is obviously an element of the deal that has been struck between Senator Harradine and the government. That must be obvious to everyone. I am sure even Senator Harradine would accept that is the case. I think it is quite disingenuous for the parliamentary secretary to come into this place and make that point in response to a serious question raised by Senator West.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—It is a pity Senator Faulkner has not taken the time to read the letter very carefully. In the third paragraph of the letter, the Prime Minister says:
I can also confirm that the Government will promote the facilitating measures concerning out of pocket costs and medical gaps previously discussed with Dr Wooldridge. These include:
And then three points:
.	 providing money for computer software development which is one of the limiting factors;
.	 changing the reinsurance pool to provide greater incentives for funds to offer no gap products; and
.	 asking Medibank Private to work on this area, as a matter of urgency.
I mentioned earlier in the debate this evening that the minister for health is pursuing those matters at length and has been for some time. The Prime Minister's letter confirms to Senator Harradine that those important objectives have a good standing. They are matters of government activity that very rightly were confirmed to Senator Harradine.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—We know that the negotiations have not just been limited to one discussion between Senator Harradine and the Prime Minister and one letter from the Prime Minister to Senator Harradine. Surely the parliamentary secretary is not going to suggest that is the case. Really and truly, you cannot con all of us all of the time, Senator Tambling. It is quite clear what has occurred here.
These things happen in politics. Deals are struck. Arrangements are come to. This is a done deal, Senator Tambling. Don't try to con me that this isn't an element—and it might even be quite an important element—of the deal that has been struck. Don't suggest for one minute, just because there were preliminary discussions and negotiations, that they don't form part of the deal. That is why I happen to believe that Senator West is entitled to a proper response to a serious question in relation to this matter when a letter like this is made public in the fashion it has.
We all know why it has been made public. We all know that, in order to get this piece of legislation through this committee, through the Senate, these arrangements have been come to between the government and Senator Harradine. A lot of people would say, `Well, that is the way the place works.' It is not that 
 unusual in politics. It is part of the political process for a deal to be struck. But let's not have sanctimonious hypocrisy from the responsible parliamentary secretary handling the bill for the government suggesting that that is not an integral part of the arrangement that has been come to.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —It is strange that Senator Faulkner would want to play theatre in an Alice in Wonderland  type of environment. Surely he is aware from his experience, both as a minister and in this place, that governments do operate multifaceted and complementary policy initiatives. The Prime Minister's letter merely confirms that there are a number of complementary policy initiatives in this area. It is quite within very good grounds to establish that in any letter to Senator Harradine, as he would with many other constituents on health issues.

name: West, Sen Sue
text: —We know that initially the government was saying that this 30 per cent tax rebate was going to cost $1.4 billion to $1.5 billion. We found out last Friday from the department that there was a mistake; it is now $1.7 billion. But on the Medibank Private work area alone, what is this going to blow the budget out to? Where is this going to take the additional costs out to?

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text: —I think the Labor Party is engaging in catch the trick type questions. This is irrelevant to this legislation. The issues relating to Medibank Private are matters relating to other areas of government policy and will be appropriately funded in those areas of government.

name: West, Sen Sue
text:
—I say to the parliamentary secretary that this is not irrelevant to this legislation. We are talking about the gap part of the insurance. We are talking about private health insurance rebates. There are costs in this to the government. What we want to know is what are the costs to the government. Is there an estimate, a guesstimate? Or are we just buying, as I said earlier, a pig in a poke—you 
 don't have any idea what it is going to do to the budget? We have the right, as a responsible opposition and as a responsible parliament, to ask what the ramifications are for these changes in terms of cost.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE AND HEALTH INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1998
The bill.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—I had listed some amendments, but as these were contingent on the passage of earlier amendments I now withdraw them.
Bill agreed to.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE) BILL 1998
The bill.

name: Lees, Sen Meg
text:
—Again, the amendments that I was to move to this bill were contingent on earlier amendments passing. As they didn't pass, I withdraw these amendments.
Bill agreed to.
Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1998 reported with amendments; Private Health Insurance Incentives Amendment Bill 1998 reported without amendments; Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance) Bill 1998 reported without amendments; report adopted.

name: Carr, Sen Kim
text:
—I present the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on a matter referred to the committee during the previous parliament. I seek leave to incorporate the report in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The report read as follows—
The References Committee met on 10 December 1998 and considered references not disposed of at the end of the 38th Parliament.
The Committee resolved to recommend to the Senate that:
The following inquiry of the 38th Parliament not be re-adopted:
The Rights and Obligations of the Media.
The Committee first reported on this matter in 1994, with its report `Off the Record: Shield Laws for Journalists' Confidential Sources'. Although the Committee believes this issue is important, it does not consider it appropriate to continue with a matter that was first referred in May 1993. It would prefer to start with a new reference on the matter and will consider this at a later time.
Senator J. McKiernan
Chair
10 December 1998
—by leave—I move:
That the report be adopted.
—I think it is always good that, when a motion is sprung on, we know what we are adopting. A report being noted is one thing. In relation to a report being adopted, it is nice if we know what we are adopting.
—It is renewal of references from the last parliament.
—Senator Margetts, I was handed this particular matter on behalf of Senator McKiernan, who I see is in the chamber. My understanding is that the references committee met on 10 December 1998 and considered references not disposed of at the end of the 38th Parliament. The committee resolved to recommend to the Senate that, firstly, the following inquiry of the 38th 
 Parliament—the rights and obligations of the media—not be re-adopted, the committee's first report on this matter in 1994, and its report of off-the-record shield laws for journalists' confidential sources. Although the committee believes the issue to be important, it does not consider it appropriate to continue with a matter that was first referred to it in May 1993. It would prefer to start with a new reference on the matter and will consider this at a later time.
—Thank you for that clarification. You can imagine why I, over the last couple of days, have been a bit careful about what I am adopting and voting on in relation to committee reports.
—I understand it was circulated before dinner, but it is better to clarify it. I put the question that the motion be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Alston, Sen Richard
text:
—I move:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
It has been a momentous year for all sorts of reasons. The election result was one that I am sure many opposite did not expect. In fact, they were very confident that they would get the opposite result. They did not and they now consign themselves to three more years of hard labour.
I do want to pay tribute to my colleagues, particularly those in the Liberal and National parties—Senator Boswell in particular for his sterling leadership of the junior coalition partner. He was there shoulder to shoulder when he was needed. He did understand the real benefits for rural Australia in a number of the policies that we took into the last election and he was prepared to see it through. So I think he deserves a particular commendation.
I would also like to pay tribute to the work of Senator Hill, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and to you, Madam President, for the way you have conducted yourself under very difficult circumstances on many occasions from the likes of me and others. You have always managed to control proceedings in a manner that has ensured that people at the end of the day respect the chair and all that ought to be respected in this chamber.
I would also like to pay particular tribute to the work of the whip and the whip's clerk, Senator Calvert and Claire Dace, who is taking leave of absence—this is well earned and I hope that we will be seeing her back here in the not too distant future. I also pay 
 tribute to Senator Coonan for her rapid ascension to a position of high eminence and her great enthusiasm and enjoyment for the role. We have certainly appreciated the work that she has carried out on our behalf.
I also pay tribute to the tremendous work of the Senate PLO, Gail Bansemer, and her assistant, Jacquie. They go beyond the call of duty, but nonetheless they are always there when needed. I would also like to thank the officials and the clerks, John Vander Wyk in particular, all Senate staff, the attendants, security, transport, Hansard and Library officers—all of whom ensure the smooth running of the Senate.
I simply conclude by hoping that the Christmas season will enable all of us to have a well-earned rest, to reflect on what might have been and what is ahead of us in the year to come. I trust that those on the other side of the chamber will come back to this Senate chamber refreshed, aware of the errors of their ways and prepared to be constructive and embrace sensible government policy. If that is the case, then we will not be having any more late night sittings. We will simply be able to get on with delivering more good government for Australia. Merry Christmas to all.

name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text:
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 10 November 1998:
(1) With reference to unfair dismissal claims under federal law, the annual report for 1996-97 of the Industrial Relations Court of Australia highlighted major outcomes in the federal jurisdiction as follows: (a) 74 per cent of unfair dismissal claims cases were settled by agreement; (b) 75 per cent of cases were finalised within 6 months and 99 per cent within 12 months; (c) 62 per cent of trials were completed in one day and 84 per cent within 2 days; (d) 58 per cent of contested cases were decided in favour of the employee, with 42 per cent in favour of the employer; (e) reinstatement of the employee was ordered in 7.5 per cent of contested cases; and (f) the median amount of compensation awarded was approximately $6 000:
Can comparable information on unfair dismissal claims for the 1997-98 financial year be provided for the following jurisdictions: (a) Federal; (b) New South Wales; (c) Queensland; (d) South Australia; (e) Tasmania; and (f) Western Australia.
(2) With reference to the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia's guess that 50 000 jobs would be created by exempting small business employers employing 15 or fewer employees from federal unfair dismissal laws: (a) how many of the estimated 50 000 jobs will be created in each state and territory; and (b) can the methodology and empirical data used to arrive at the jobs estimate creation in each jurisdiction be provided.
(3) With reference to the answer to paragraph (1) of question on notice no. 1005 (Senate Hansard, 4 March 1998, p.421), for each of the jurisdictions outlined in the table provided, can numbers be given, accompanied by evidence and methodology for: (a) jobs created or lost as a result of increases or decreases in unfair dismissal applications; and (b) separate answers for federal, state and territory jurisdictions based on comparative 1996-97 data.

name: Alston, Sen Richard
text:
—The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
(1) Answers for each of the five State unfair dismissal regimes are unavailable.
The 1997-8 Annual Report of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission contains some statistics in relation to resolution of unfair dismissal claims. However, the Australian Industrial Registry does not collect data on all of the subjects on which the Industrial Relations Court of Australia previously collected data. Therefore, statistics in relation to federal unfair dismissal claims can only be provided for parts (a), (d) and (e).
(a) There were 8,092 termination of employment applications lodged under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 in 1997-98. Of those applications, 6,303 (78 per cent) were settled by agreement (ie had been withdrawn, settled or otherwise discontinued prior to conciliation or settled at conciliation or withdrawn, discontinued or otherwise settled after conciliation but prior to final orders).
(d) There were 774 contested federal cases decided in 1997-98, with 311 (40 per cent) decided in favour of the employer and 463 (60 per cent) in favour of the employee. (It may be noted that 282 of the decisions in favour of the employee involved applications against Gordonstone Coal Management based on the same fact situation; if these 282 applications are treated as one class action, then 63 per cent of contested cases would have been decided in favour of the employer and 37 per cent in favour of the employee.)
(e) Reinstatement was awarded in only 17 (2 per cent) of the 774 contested federal cases.
(2) The Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations Australia, Mr Rob Bastian, based his estimate that 50 000 jobs would be created if small businesses were exempt from federal unfair dismissal laws on the, in his view conservative, premise that 1 in 20 small businesses would hire at least one more employee if the exclusion was to come into force.
Applying this formula to the percentage of small businesses in each State or Territory (according to data published in Small Business in Australia 1997, ABS Cat No. 1321.0), approximately 16 500 jobs would be created in NSW, 12 500 in VIC, 9 500 in QLD, 4 000 in SA, 5 500 in WA, 1 000 in TAS and 500 each in the ACT and NT.

There are a number of factors that contribute to the differences in labour market performance across the States and Territories. For example, the States and Territories generally rely on different industries for economic and employment growth. As such, any changes in policy or economic conditions which affect sectors in a non-uniform manner can be expected to have different impacts on employment. Similarly, characteristics such as population size and growth, natural attributes and climatic conditions also contribute to the differences in employment growth.
The reduction in the number of unfair dismissal applications indicates that progress has been made under the current legislation in discouraging inappropriate applications. This in itself would not be expected to create additional jobs in the small business sector. The Government considers that further change is required to recognise the particular circumstances of small businesses as well as to provide greater certainty for employers about the length of an employee's employment before that person can initiate an unfair dismissal application (no change is proposed in respect of unlawful dismissal applications). It is necessary to provide security for employers that they will not be subject to inappropriate applications. This is provided for in the Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill 1998, presently before the Parliament.
